Coli breakout), spit fired Mary's chicken, pickled red onion, navel oranges, fennel, mizthira cheese, pea shoots and "granch" dressing.  I'm guessing granch is a Greek ranch dressing.  It's a loaded and filling salad.  The chicken was moist and plentiful.  Loved the light citrus from the orange, the tang from the pickled onions.  The cheese was perfectly balanced (sometimes feta can be a bit strong).  Oh and I had some of their fries too our first time which were perfectly crisp and seasoned with the same cheese, olive oil, lemon juice and parsley.

If I find myself dining in instead of taking out, I would love to sample one of their Greek yogurts.  It's a Hayes Valley gem for somewhat healthy, quick and pleasing food.

I have a few friends who rave about Souvla. Since my first experience was pretty much just okay, I decided to give them another shot. The main part of my weekly office lunch arrived on Friday, November 9th around 12:15pm.

I got the Lamb Sandwich: Spit-roasted Superior Farms leg of lamb with harissa-spiked yogurt, cucumber, radish, pickled red onion, and feta cheese wrapped in warm and fluffy pita bread, Yogurt on the Side ($14), add Side of Souvla Hot Sauce (+$0.50). The meat inside was pretty good. Had a nice smokiness to it. I liked the mixture of veggies, but I didn't care for the yogurt. I thought it was too thick to meld the whole sandwich into a cohesive bite. The hot sauce also wasn't very spicy. I ended up just using one of the hot sauces I had at my desk. I'd suggest saving the 50 cents and using another hot sauce if you really want some heat.

Maybe Souvla just isn't my cup of tea. Giving them 3 stars as I did enjoy the meat and veggies.

It's worth the hype (I've been twice so far and can't wait to go back and try more)..here's why:
+ I've only tried the chicken wrap and Greek fries but I love both so much! The fries are such a perfect thickness and crispiness and not overly garlic-y. The chicken wrap is filling and delicious and the orange in it is so refreshing and complements the overall flavors.
+ even though it's popular, they are efficient and they take orders quickly and food doesn't take too long to come out either!
+ the Greek yogurt!!! Highly recommend trying if you come - I got the one with baklava toppings which was pretty good, not overly sweet since the tartness of the yogurt balances out the sweet pastry toppings 
+ gorgeous outdoor seating (love the outdoor lights)

- the chicken in the wrap is a little dry/wish there was more white sauce but it's still pretty good
- not cheap but it's sf so what do u expect 
- wish they had better veggie options/falafel since I don't love sweet potato

Looking forward to my next visit when I'll likely try their rosè and the salad (salad looks pretty big so you'll probably have leftovers unless you eat a lot or come super hungry).

I was looking for small and something quick to eat while in the Mission. I honestly never order a salad as a main dish and I personally think it's not really worth it (in my opinion). Walking into this place I saw a very nice and minimal interior. That's one of my favorite things about SF cause a lot of places have very tasteful decor. Aside from that i saw chicken being grilled and was instantly hungry. I have been told they are known for their big bowl of delicious Greek fries but I didn't want anything too heavy so for on a rare occasion I ordered a salad to split and I was pretty skeptical (because I never order a salad at a restaurant). 

[ SALAD AS A MAIN DISH IS NOT WORTH IT, CHANGE MY MIND]

Let alone, I ordered the free range chicken salad and once it came out I was pretty excited to try it. The first thing that caught my eye were tangerines, again I never was a fan having fruit in a salad like berries and etc. But I can say that my ignorance was making me miss out about how well this paired with the salad. From the dressing, the pea shoots and the chicken, it was the best salad I've had. I feel like I'm only saying that cause, you know... but I'll be honest, this definitely changed my perception about seeing if salads are worth it when ordering as a main dish. Since I got a full bowl split in half I can say that I left satisfied and light. I will honestly look forward coming back here and order a Greek fries as well. 

I no longer think salads are a waste of money.

I'm a bit confused with the hype here. 

For some reason, I keep coming back to give it another chance, even when I know I'm not going to be full after. Is this the magic of souvla? 

Fries are good but expensive. For $6+ I don't want to pay another $1 for a sauce. 

Salad is bright and seasoned well but doesn't feel... substantial? I wish they gave you pita on the side to give you more of an oomph to your meal. 

Highlight is definitely their lemon orzo soup- wouldnt get this by itself but it's nice on a cold day with fries or a wrap! 

The flavor is definitely there, it's just so pricey for what you get and leaves you wanting more.

Visited the Hayes Valley Souvla on a Sunday morning. My friend and I arrived about 10 minutes before they opened at noon and were third in line. The line gets longer as the day goes on, so getting there early was a plus!

I ordered a Lamb Gyro and enjoyed it. The pita was warm and had plenty of olive oil, and the tzatziki and feta were zippy and lovely. The lamb chunks were large and a bit fatty. This gyro is truly for the lamb lovers out there and is heavy on the lamb.

The true star of the meal was the Baklava Greek Frozen Yogurt. My friend encouraged me to try it and wow!! The Greek yogurt has wonderful tangy notes that were very refreshing. The sweetness of the baklava paired with the tangy yogurt perfectly. The baklava had an amazing texture as well. All around a super star dessert and something I'll be back to have again and again!!

We sat at a one of the tables that now spill out into the street. Hayes street is closed to cars right now, and there are several tables in the street to sit at and enjoy your meal.

I don't usually order salads because I don't believe it's worth the price. But this was about the only option since I don't eat meat. I got the white sweet potato salad and it was delicious. Definitely more filling that I expected it to be. There was lots of lettuce and kale and olives. The dressing was nice and creamy. Great balance! I highly recommend getting this AND the Greek fries (basically garlic fries).

Not your traditional Greek restaurant, everything has a bit of flair, ex. Oranges in your chicken sandwich, pea shoots etc. this is visually appealing, however, it doesn't seem to be a cohesive flavor that works as anything other than a fancying up of traditional dishes. 

Food:
Chicken Sandwich: dry and flavorless, could've used a sauce, wouldn't get again. Also the oranges don't work with the chicken because it's so dry and the orange is juicy, the different textures are a bit shocking. 

Veg Salad: decent, ordered because it's their only veg option, sweet potato was cooked wonderfully, however, I echo the sentiment of a different user that said it's a little acidic and has a fair amount of cheese which they rely on for a lot of the flavor. 

Baklava Crumble and Honey Greek Yogurt: the saving grace of this meal. The tart Greek frozen yogurt pairs nicely with the honey, a bit too much sweetness in the crumbles for my taste but otherwise an exceptional dessert option. (The reason for 2 stars vs 1).

Juicy Potatoes: this was the dish I was most excited about and the most disappointed in. The potatoes are so bland it is just a carton of boiled potatoes cut in half and light sautéed in almost an entire stick of butter that drips off of the potatoes when you eat them. No salt, no pepper, I took them home and seasoned them, leaving most of the butter behind, and threw them in a breakfast burrito.

Greek Iced Tea: this doesn't pair well with the flavors of their food, it's much too honey flavored and the bits of tea leaves in the drink come into your mouth with every sip which makes it pretty dominating with a meal, and it's not tasty enough for me to order on its own. Sadly threw most of mine away. 

They are following safety guidelines, service is fast, and the entire surrounding area of Hayes Valley is a cute place to walk and shop/ browse safely. Parking was difficult to find but it's SF.

I. Love. Souvla.

It's my favorite place to eat in Hayes Valley. The order at the counter situation can feel a bit hectic, but I'm always able to find a table. 

I've had every wrap they have, and they're all great! The pita is so fluffy. My favorite is the veggie, the white sweet potatoes are delicious. 

You have to get fries with a dipping sauce. Their fries are flavorful and the right amount of crispy with a little soft was on the inside. One order is definitely enough for two people to share. 

You can also get the food as salads. I've only ever had the chicken salad, since the oranges feel like a refreshing addition to salad. The come with creamy dressing, so it doesn't feel too healthy, but it's still a nice alternative to all that bread.

I decided to check this place out because it is new and some of my friends recommended it. I was very happy I came . The only drawback is that it is very hard to find parking so I would recommend walking or taking an Uber.  I brought my friend here for dinner and we ordered the exact same thing.  We got the chicken sandwich, cheery soda and frozen greek yogurt.  The chicken was juicy and it was literally dripping with flavor!  The chicken was so moist and tender!  The pita bread was warm and topped with chicken, lettuce, cheese, red onions and mandarin oranges. The flavor was refreshing and savory!  The cheery soda was ok the small side, but barely enough. I really liked the frozen greek yogurt!  It was not overly sweet, it was creamy and sour, but not overpowering.  I will definitely return to this place!   Overall the meal was delicious and satisfying!  I highly recommend this place and if you are in SF come check it out!

The food was fresh but when I got to the bottom of my food I found a small black hair in it. I threw it out not thinking much and kept eating. Then it happened again! I found another one. Then I stopped eating and told the management. I threw the rest in the trash and left. I feel grossed out now.
The food had no flavor except for lamb meat and I had to add salt and pepper  every few bites to make it a little seasoned. I asked for some sauce and they wanted $1 for a tiny little cup and I told them that the food was bland and she just gave it to me.
They were not very friendly either, whenever we needed something, like silverware or water refill they acted like we were bothering them.
Ordered a lamb salad and the meat was very dry. Pretty disappointed compared to what they used to serve.
Everything was amazing, I will say though the side potatoes dont have much flavor so get the fries instead. The veggie sandwich is incredible

Finally got the chance to give these guys a try last Sunday!  There was a large group people waiting for their orders so everyone was excited they had finally opened back again.

Their Greek yogurt with baklava and honey is everything everyone has been saying.  Hearty portion of baklava tempered with just the right amount of honey.  NtG is quite the opposite, skimping on the baklava and overdoing it with the honey.  The yogurt was just a delicious having the nice little tang one expects from Greek yogurt.  The portion size was spot on.

My lamb gyro/sandwich was equally delicious a few hours later for dinner.  Nice big chunks of meet balancing the veggies, etc.  Yum!

We will definitely be back whenever we are in The City!

The most delicious frozen Greek yogurt with baklava that I've ever had. 

I was in San Francisco for a conference and I visited Souvla, for the first time, with a friend. Wow! Absolutely delicious. I had something similar in Los Angeles, but Souvla was the real deal. I am featuring the Baklava Crumbles and Honey Syrup. 

Parking looked non-existent. I took an Uber to the area. There's a nice, small park nearby where you can enjoy your yogurt.

Super cute and trendy spot in Hayes Valley next to the park! Seating is limited so we ordered to-go. They gave us a number to wait outside and the food came out relatively quickly.

I got the chicken salad with Greek fries, and the often-recommended baklava honey frozen yogurt. I really enjoyed the fresh creaminess of the yogurt, although it was more tart than I expected. The honey baklava topping was absolutely perfect and my favorite part of the whole meal :)

The chicken was flavorful and tender and I really enjoyed the orange slices in the salad. The greens were fresh and crispy but the dressing was a little too oily for me. I loved the shredded mizithra cheese on both the fries and salad. Next time I'll try to eat in-store because I think takeout made the fries soggy! 

Overall a great spot for takeout or eating in, with fresh high-quality ingredients. Would definitely come back!

I felt stressed here! 

I placed my usual order of side salad with lamb and Greek fries and tried to find seating inside since it was cold and windy out. There was none to be had. All the counter seats, stools by the wall and the small cramped space by the window was quickly taken by others who haven't even ordered yet. There's no waiting area so a bunch of us who did to go orders kinda just stood in the middle of the dining room waiting for our food while servers and other diners passed by on the way to the kitchen and bathroom. 

I got my order after 15 minutes and my fries were not even piping hot. That's disappointing! As I was leaving, I saw a homeless guy swipe a bunch of napkins from the diners who were sitting outside. 

Terribly crowded, in the middle of a super busy pedestrian sidewalk and homeless people just within an arm's length of your $15 lamb salad. No thanks!!!

i can't remember how long souvla has been on my list. finally on this random day i was walking on valencia st and realized SOUVLA IS HERE!

i only had the stomach to eat a cup of yogurt and knowing they are famous for it so i quickly decided to get the one with honey.

tbh the honey was a mistake. since it's frozen greek yogurt, the honey drizzle soon became hard on top but still sticky at the same time. the yogurt was sweet enough itself. honey was good but just not necessary 

ooookay now let's talk about the yogurt. actually nah i already miss it and want to go again? is it enough to convince you to go? it's so good. i've had lots of sugary creamy tasting frozen yogurt in the states - some are good but far from what my understanding of a frozen yogurt is like. souvla meets all my expectations. it's has the sour tart taste you want from yogurt with the right amount of sugar inside to balance it. 

if you don't have a particular sweet tooth, u gotta try their yogurt out!!!!!

Nothing hits the spot like a giant cup of frozen yogurt on a rare sunny day in SF! I was craving something sweet and ended up ordering the frozen yogurt with baklava crumbles. The yogurt was perfectly tart and paired really well with the sweetness of the baklava! The portion was pretty large so I'd recommend sharing one. 

I think the best thing about souvla though was the back patio they had! Perfect for catching some sun and ultimately just a relaxing environment.

Sandwich or salad, you can't go wrong picking this spot to HIT the spot. I always order the chicken sandwich with a side of garlic fries. The chicken salad is just as good and not too far behind the sandwich calorie FYI. It's a large portion and delicious! I've tried the lamb and if that's more your jam, order it. When life wasn't COVID-19, the restaurant got packed give its limited seating. right now, you can pick up at the window only so order ahead unless you don't mind strolling Hayes. Love this spot!

Souvla's menu is very simple. You either pick a wrap or a salad bowl with a choice of chicken, lamb,  pork. There is also a veg wrap or salad. 

Their chicken wrap was good. The wrap consist of pulled roasted chicken with pea shoots, pickle red onions, navel oranges, mizithra cheese, and a homemade dressing.

We also ordered a side of Greek fries with parsley and mizithra cheese. The fries was also good. 

Souvla also serves a frozen Greek yogurt with different selection of toppings. I recommend the Baklava and honey syrup. The frozen yogurt has a slightly tart taste which balance the sweetest of the Baklava and honey syrup. 

At Souvla you order at the counter, and your order is delivered to your seat. Overall, our order arrived within 5 minutes after we ordered our meal.

went there today and pretty disappointed. $17 for a salad before tax and tips and the chicken was dry. $8 for a baklava yogurt was really overpriced. I know there's an inflation going on but come on charging $8 for a yogurt is really exploiting the inflation situation. My partner and I used to come here very often but I guess it will be our last time, at least for a while

Another restaurant that changed to worse, another disappointment!. And it was one of my favorites... I ordered the kitchen salad that lacked taste, had less mandarines, less chicken that also was very golden dry... Too much kale... not the yummy, sweet, tangy, balanced, filling salad I use to love here.

4.5 star. My go-to Greek casual restaurant in the city. They typically have a line, but it does move quickly. There's some limited seating in the inside, but also on the outside. However, turnover doesn't seem to be an issue.
Can choose between chicken, lamb, pork, or vegetable as a pita sandwich or salad. Both are solid options. My favorite is probably the pork as it is very succulent. Make sure to get the Greek fries seasoned in olive oil, parsley and cheese. 
PRO TIP: head over to Salt and Straw around the corner for dessert!

The Frozen Greek Yogurt with Baclava and Honey was sublime! The yogurt itself is creamy, refreshing, and truly tastes like Greek Yogurt it comes from. Not too sweet, with a fresh tartiness, that makes it extra smooth and satisfying. The warm baclava is a genius addition that blends magnificently with the yogurt, and the honey sweetens it all up. Fast service, cute vibe with outdoor seating, and a great deal as well!

I love Greek food and I've been wanting to try Souvla for awhile now. Having dined at Novy in Noe Valley just yesterday, I am clearly on a roll. 

It's a very casual place, almost like fast food except the quality is so much better. It was a gorgeous day and we were able to snag a great table outside. 

We had the chicken gyro, the lamb gyro and those oh so necessary garlic fries. 

Lamb Gyro
Harissa spikes yogurt sauce, cucumber, radish, pickled red onion and feta cheese. 

The lamb was tender, the flavors had depth and the fresh veggies added a nice crunch. I didn't find there to be a lot of yogurt sauce and did not at all get the hot of harissa at all. My biggest disappointment is that this was barely warm despite the fact that we picked it up as soon as it was ready. 

Same story with our garlic fries :(. And no one, I mean no one likes barely warm French fries. We were there at right around 130, so there's no reason we needed to wait for food that wasn't even barely warm...

Chicken Gyro
Mary's free range chicken, "Granch" dressing, fennel, navel orange, pickled red onion, pea shoots and mizithra cheese. 

The chicken was kind of shredded, moist and very flavorful. I didn't love the orange but I did love all the other veggies; those pea shoots were a great addition. Again, it was barely warm so that was a disappointment. But the flavors were all there and it's worth ordering. 

We had some sauce to sip the fries in (there's a few choices) and we took the one they recommended which I think was the "Granch". I give it a meh. Fries were actually better without it. 

We also ordered an iced tea and it actually came in a bottle and is imported from Greece. Flavor was really nice and subtle. But at $4 bottle a bit pricey when you're used to endless iced tea. 

All in all a good lunch despite the lack of warmth for the food. I'd go back again but make sure everything came out hot.

Stopped by for the famous frozen yogurt! Well worth the hype! $5 for a heaping cup with baklava. Sweet and tart and delicious! They currently have a few tables for indoor dining (limited) and outdoor seats set up

When one of my good friends took me out to lunch one day, we decided to eat here (hell if it weren't for her I probably wouldn't have been able to explore half of SF thanks to her- you rock JZ!).  It was about a 5 minute walk from her place.  

I will never forget the amazing pics she took of the yogurt and food here, so when she said we were finally going, I was ecstatic.  I think she nailed the head on the wall when she said that Greek food is hard to find out in SF.  I can see it, since it is on the Pacific and not the Atlantic.  However, with newer flights to Europe out of OAK and SFO, maybe that will slowly change!

This place is pretty small and can get very busy if you don't hit it at the right times.  It looks like there are 3 locations now with a 4th one opening up in the Marina District.  This is the only one I have been to.  

The menu is simple, but slightly pricey, but it looks like the stuff is pretty quality.  Expect to pay at least $20 PP for lunch after tax and tip (for a sandwich and drink).  Add sides and dessert, and that will surely go up.  They have 4 different types of meat here, and you can get them via sandwich (pita) or salad.  Here is a current menu with the pricing for you: souvla.com/menus

Apparently on the weekends, they even do brunch breakfast sandwich, but I never had the chance to indulge in it.  It looks pretty tasty!  But, the only thing I have ordered is the lamb sandwich, and the frozen yogurt.

Now, I will forewarn you again, this place is small, and I am big, so eating quick is the best thing for us big folk.  Hell, they even have a spot at the front window that I could totally dwarf, and I saw 2 people somehow manage to squeeze in that spot.  Sorry, but I need some elbow room to eat!

The lamb sandwich is pretty decent, and I am not usually a fan of red onion, but in this case, it gave a nice crunch and flavor profile to the meat.  It was the perfect size for a sandwich.  But, at $14, there is no way I would get 2 of them LOL.  

Now, the yogurt.  I tell you what, some can say what they want, but this is one of the simplest and tastiest desserts I have had in SF.  There are a lot to battle, but this sticks out because it is Greek soft serve, and has a nice zing to it.  The honey and baklava balanced it out.  Coating my stomach with that after eating the lamb I wanted to tell myself I actually had a healthy lunch- something that is typically hard for me to say!

Check this place out if you want solid Greek with some SF vibes.  Oh yea, I forgot to mention, they serve your food on some nice plates, but the yogurt in a plastic cup, maybe they want you to take that thing to go so you can free up the table! haha.

Came here at around 6pm on a weekday and it was packed. The line to order was out the door but it moved very quickly. My friend and I got a number card for our order and we were lucky to find a table right away. Since they gave me a number stand for my order, I thought the food will be served to our table but instead, I have to pick them up at the window counter. It was a little chaotic there because there were a mix of people who are lining up to order and waiting for their food. 

We got the pork salad, the Greek fries and the Greek frozen yogurt with baklava crumbles.

Pork shoulder salad $13 (3/5)
The salad tasted very fresh with the pickled onions. The pork was well seasoned but on the dry side. There was way too much feta on the salad for my preference. Comparing to other places that serve salad in SF, this is only mediocre for the price. 

Greek fries $5 (3.7/5)
There are a lot of negative comments on the fries but surprisingly this tasted much better than I anticipated. They were crispy at the end parts with the potato skin and soft and fluffy in the middle. Personally I prefer my fries to be more crispy but they were delicious with the cheese. It will be better if they came out hotter.

Greek yogurt with baklava crumbles $5 (4/5)
I would give this 5/5 if I don't count the baklava crumble. The frozen yogurt tasted on point with the perfect balance of sour and sweetness. A good baklava would have a crispy texture from the fillo dough and crunchy texture from the chopped nuts if baked perfectly but the ones here are all mushed together into chucks and tasted a little bit stale. I highly recommend trying the yogurt since that was the highlight of our meal but definitely not with the baklava crumble. 

I will come back for the yogurt if I am in the area but probably not for the other food on the menu.

Got the baklava crumbles and syrup frozen yogurt.  Yogurt was tart and cream and was balanced nicely with the sweet baklava. At first it didn't look like there was enough baklava but it was actually portioned out nicely. Will be back next time we're in the area!

Souvla has been on my try list for a while, and I finally got a chance to go. I went with a dear friend and got there before the lunch crowd. You order at the front, get a number and seat yourself. I asked if I should order the Greek yogurt now or later and they told me now, I could always hand the cashier the receipt after our meal to get our Greek Yogurt. 

I ordered:

Chicken Sandwich (Mary's Free Ranch Chicken, "Granch" dressing, Fennel, Navel Orange, Pickled Red Onion, Pea Shoots, Mizithra Cheese: I really enjoyed my sandwich, there was a lot of shredded chicken and I loved the texture and flavors of the pickled red onion and navel orange with the chicken. I wish there was a little bit more Granch dressing - I should have poured some of the Granch dip I got with my fries in the sandwich.

Greek Fries with "Granch" Greek Yogurt: Fries were crispy and went well with the Granch dressing.

Greek yogurt with Baklava crumbles and honey sryup: WOW. I loved this. This is by far my favorite, the tangy yogurt and honey syrup went really well together. And the Baklava crumbles made this dessert even more delicious. 

A great place for a casual meal and good food. Highly recommended!

Order first and pay at the front. They will bring the food to you afterwards.

I had the Mediterranean chicken sandwich, which I thought was decent. On the blander side even with hot sauce. Chicken was a bit too dry. Quick for grab and go. Nothing special tbh. 

This place has a good amount of seating, but difficult to find during Saturday for dinner. We ended up sitting outside, which was a bit chilly in the summer.
Complete robbery. Overhyped. The prices are absolutely ludicrous for what they serve. I have no plans to go back.

Tasty and fast lunch spot in Hayes Valley. Arrived at 1pm and there was a line which went by very quickly. I ordered the pork "sandwich" which looks more like a wrap. Very tasty. Generous portions. 

After you pay at the front, you find your own seat and pour your own water. Folks move in and out of this place pretty quickly so it's possible to find a seat--even during peak hours.

This place is consistently good. Love the chicken sandwich/wrap, the oranges pair so well with the other flavors in the wrap. Got the pickled onions on the side but they were delicious ! The fries are a must but the potatoes are really good too! If you like hot sauce then you have to try the souvla hot sauce it's really good ! Love this place and will be coming back soon!

Variety of vegetarian options on the menu: 3/5

So I totally get that the fine print under the Souvla brand is "Spit-Fired Meats." As in that is a part of the restaurant name. That being said, their Vegetarian entree is one of the most amazing combination of flavors and food items I've ever had. I wish I discovered this joint sooner, but randomly my friends told me about it after they had been ordering this vegetarian item for months. So rude; I wish they told me earlier.

I've only ever gotten the salad version, but I'm sure the sandwich is just as good (not sure what bread they use though). The roasted white sweet potato adds a great texture, and the garlic yogurt sauce complements it with its cooler temperature. I also really enjoyed the Mizhithra cheese; super unique and authentic. Been making my own pickled onion since I had that salad as well!

Ok and THEN the dessert! Oh wow that greek yogurt just came out of left field and knocked my socks off. It is so fresh and the tartness is just perfect that it feels like you're having a healthy snack. I went for the sea salt and olive oil which was pretty bold, although I've been told the sour cherry syrup or wildflower honey is better. Anyway get to this place asap!

if there was a Souvla close to where I go to school I would literally eat there every day until my loans tell me otherwise. I have not had a pita wrap with such a unique, fresh, flavorful chicken filling in it EVER. The citrus pairing with the oils and the chicken is a genius combo so props to the sous chef! The meat is SO moist. It's hard to do a chicken pita wrap well unless you douse it with some creamy sauce. There was a slight drizzle of a yogurt based sauce on the wrap but the natural flavors of all the ingredients in the wrap shone through. The side salad is simple and fresh and great if you're looking for a healthier option but honestly the wrap is a 10/10 health wise if you're not training to be a bikini model. 

The place is worth the lunch line and the hype! Interior is super cute too--white and beach blue themed, just like Santorini. They even serve coffee in Greek cups. Authenticity with a modern twist, just to be adored. I would love to return to try the other menu items!!!

All in all, Souvla's Hayes location has been on the decline for the past few years. From long lines, ever-increasing prices to ever-decreasing portions, and charging for everything from napkins, utensils to ketchup, what once was a "must-have" in San Francisco now is rather forgettable. 

Both lamb and pork, while tasty, are uncomfortably oily, even when eaten in salad form. Their chicken remains a healthier choice although suffers from dryness. If you've had Souvla before, chances are you'll try it, and even like it, many more times. However, by no means is it worth a trip to the beautiful Hayes Street.

Quite the popular place for all locations. Souvla can build up quite the line, but it moves reasonably quick. I usually grab the frozen yogurt with baclava if I want to get out quickly. The fries come out hot and crispy; if you're carrying it out, make sure to open the box so it doesn't get soggy. For the main entree, I got the chicken gyro and appreciated the navel oranges. Overall, it was tasty and light.

My friends are in love with the place, which I don't fully get lol.

Just thinking about what I'm gonna write is making me want to eat here again. Right now. Plus it's lunch break so this would be PERFECT. And it's also pretty hot over here so some Greek frozen yogurt would be the most perfect ending to my imaginary encore Souvla lunch. 

We came here for a late lunch and I am glad it was a little late because I'm sure at a prime hour, this place is hard to get a seat. Super cute space with seating outside and inside. The outside tables were already occupied but the inside was so cute so I was glad to sit on the tall tables with the high stools inside the restaurant. 

When we walked in, we were greeted by the owner and right away, my son spocks out the frozen greek yogurt machine. The owner was so nice, he gave my little monster a small sample which of course, being the ice cream-yogurt-soft serve-anything frozen dairy-monster that I am, I had to take a lick of that. I almost wanted to just order and eat that before actual lunch!

Luckily the menu is not very large which is good for me because I am probably the most indecisive person everrrrr. We decided on the chicken and the lamb dishes which were both delicious. I am not a lamb eater but this was hands down the best lamb dish I have ever eaten. The lamb was tender and soft and very tasty. It was served with harissa-spiked yogurt, cucumbers, radish, red onions, and feta cheese. The chicken was also good with a different type of dressing, fennel, orange, red onion, pea shoots, and a mizithra cheese. Different flavors but both DELICIOUS. Both were wrapped in delicious pita. We also ordered the greek fries which were yummy and tasty. 

Of course you know we HAD to get some of the REAL GREEK frozen yogurt for dessert. We had it with the baklava crumbles and ohhhhhh, you have to get this if you like baklava like I do. Don't get me wrong, this frozen yogurt tastes wonderful by itself. It was tart which is hands down my favorite yogurt flavor. Plus, it was REAL GREEK frozen yogurt so how can you go wrong?

If you love Greek food like I do, or just love frozen yogurt like I do, give this place a try if you're in the area!

this place is one of my go-tos when i'm in the city! this place is enforcing social distancing by closing their dining areas and when you order there are separate windows for ordering and pickup with a plexiglass separating you from the employees. if there's people waiting for their orders, they have 6ft distance stickers on where to stand. 

if you've never been here, my all time favorite is definitely their frozen greek yogurt with baklava crumbles and honey syrup!! i shared this with my boyfriend but i definitely wish I got my own. I also really like their avgolemono soup, if you really like a lemony creamy coup then this is the soup for you!! its definitely very filling since there's rice and chicken in it too. their salads are also pretty good and a decent size which I didn't expect but i would also definitely try the sandwiches which are basically like a street pita with your choice of meat and their toppings listed on the menu. usually i would only come here for dessert but their sandwiches are pretty good. pro tip, if you want an extra level of flavor on the dessert, get the greek olive oil & sea salt frozen yogurt and add baklava crumbles its so good i highly recommend!

I'm actually not a huge fan of Mediterranean food but I still wanted to try this place because I heard so many good things about it. I came here for lunch on Sunday and the line was slightly out the door, but the line moves pretty quickly. Most of the Souvla locations are pretty small, so be prepared to wait a bit to get seats; or you could just come earlier too. 

The pork wrap was really nice and juicy - the sauce that came with it was delicious and pair very well with the pork. The pita bread was also soft and fluffy! My friend and I also go the chicken wrap, which was a bit of a disappointment because the chicken was quite dry, and the wrap didn't actually come with any sauce. The mandarin oranges were a nice touch tho.

Greek fries were good, even though we didn't get a dipping sauce. The frozen greek yogurt with baklava and honey was bomb - and the perfect amount of sweetness - you MUST save stomach space for the frozen yogurt!!

I came during during noon on Sunday and the line was slightly out the door. However, it didn't take long to get to the register and order. Seating was full so I recommend coming earlier.

My friend and I ordered:

- pork wrap: tasted okay. The meat was good and the cucumbers and baby tomatoes complements well.
- chicken wrap: chicken was dried and the overall wrap could use some sauce. The orange slices was a nice touch.
- Greek fries: yum!
- Greek yogurt with baklava and honey: A+

I would probably go back again only for the Greek yogurt with baklava.

Notes:
- The inside was cute and a nice, casual atmosphere to chat.
- There's one unisex restroom inside.
- There's some cute shops to walk around after your meal

Overrated. Expensive. 

Ordered- lamb sandwich. 

Meat dry AND dripping with grease? Nothing juicy about this at all. Inedible and spit it out cause dried out my mouth chewing. Pita tastes old. Not even enough sauce. If I could I'd give negative stars. No love in this meal.

I'm really bummed since I used to eat here a lot...

Last weekend, I got a salad... I've been having GI problems for the past two days that won't go away...

Every time I've been here, there's always been a line out the door, and it's for a good reason.

If you're here with another person, I highly suggest that one stays in line while the other goes and hunts down a table.

Souvla's menu is simple - choose your protein and whether you'd like it in a wrap or salad. I always get their pork salad. My s/o got the lamb wrap once and mentioned that it was a bit dry, so either ask for more sauce or just get a bowl of meat with veg! 

Their fries are also a must order. They're always fresh and hot. No dipping sauce needed, although you can ask for ketchup. I've seen some customers order fries on top of their salads and inside of their wraps, as well! If you're not a big eater, you'd easily be able to split the salad along with some fries. 

As for drinks, their white wine is delish. There's also self serve water near the register.

I've never tried their yogurt, but the flavors all look heavenly. One day, I'll have to pass up Salt & Straw and try the greek yogurt at Souvla instead!

Great combination of flavors, ingredients, and colors. I got the chicken salad which was full of flavor and texture. Their kale was so soft and the chicken was juicy and tender. I never like having fruits in my salad though so I had to pick out the oranges (which were really good on its own). Besides that and the slightly too salty sauce, I enjoyed eating my salad very much. It was super filling, large, and not terribly priced ~$13-15. 

The space, however, was tiny. On a warmer day, I would have opted to eat out in the park or at their standing tables outside but not when it's 40 degrees outside. Expectedly, the place was very crowded when I went and we had to pounce on the first available space after ordering. If you order a yogurt, you can pick it up later as long as you keep your receipt. (They are a pay and take a number type place). 

I also got the baklava greek yogurt ($5) and it was delicious. Unsure why the baklava was so jam-like; it felt mostly like hardened honey and was pretty sweet. The yogurt itself was smooth, sweet, and slightly sour which paired well with the drizzled honey (not as much with the baklava which was slightly overpowering). I tried the olive oil/sea salt one and it was pretty unique as well.

Overall a solid place that I would frequent more if I lived nearby.

Besides the delicious wraps, salads, and greek yogurt, the customer service at Souvla is phenomenal. My experience here was nothing but positive!

There are two ways you can order here. You can either order at the window outside or you can order inside. I decided to eat inside to avoid the violently cold breezes that kept attacking me. My order was taken by Alejandra, who gave me enough time to order. I didn't feel rushed by her at all. As I waited on my lamb wrap I was asked about my day by Alejandra (which isn't always asked by associates) but for her to ask was thoughtful. After that we were having a casual conversation and not even 3 minutes went by when I was greeted to my lamb wrap. Souvla is very quick and does NOT mess around. 

There's outside seating and a self-service station for water. The restroom is clean, the restaurant's atmosphere is welcoming, and the music selection is excellent. 

I will be coming back for brunch next time I'm in San Francisco. I will be coming back for the delectable lamp wrap, amiable staff, especially Alejandra, who was attentive, sweet, and always had a smile on her face.

I think this may be 3 stars more because of all the hype and it was a bit of a disappointment. If I hadn't been expecting angels singing and unicorns grazing it may have been better. Don't get me wrong, the food is good. It's fresh, made with care and pretty tasty, but it wasn't as over the top as I was expecting.

The side salad was nice, fresh, very healthy and well dressed. Roasted potatoes in chicken fat were luxurious and well cooked. The lamb souvlaki pita was just ok. Not much flavor, but it was fresh. Wished it was also a bit bigger with more meat. It's a great space, fits the fast casual moniker, but I wouldn't line up for 30 minutes to eat here like the lines sometimes are on the weekends.

Souvla is one of my favorite spots in SF. It's trendy, tasty, and just sooo good. I love Mediterranean food, and this place is the perfect combination of quality food with fast, to-go food. 

We found street parking nearby pretty easily. The restaurant was crowded, with a few spots open to eat. It is first come, first served on seating. So we had to squeeze into two seats for three of us. At souvla, you can pick between a salad or pita with your choice of meat: lamb, chicken, pork (?) and maybe another type. I've tried the lamb pita before, so I decided to get the lamb salad this time. 

Although it costs $15 for a salad, the serving is huge and they are generous with the lamb chunks inside. The base was a mix of kale and romaine lettuce. And the salad was topped with feta cheese, lamb, onions, and dressing. It was so good! The salads or pita are equally as good. The meat is seasoned well and they give a generous serving with any type of dish. 

For dessert, you have to try the greek yogurt soft serve. The baklava one is my favorite, but I have heard nothing but great things about all the other flavors. It's probably best to share after a meal since its quite big, but I got one all for myself since I wouldn't be back in a while!

Souvla has done a good thing by mixing up the traditional greek slouvaki- and its pretty good! The flavors and different textures in their wrap blend well plus taste good together! Lucky for i was able to taste test the chicken, pork and veggie- I'm a fan. Whether it was in a salad or sandwich- it's good stuff!

This place is so hipster it hurts but the lamb gyro wrap was really good (you can taste the freshness of the lamb and all the ingredients that goes into it). Also ordered the frozen Greek Yogurt with olive oil and sea salt and the Greek iced tea and those were good as well.  

Come early (or late) since the line gets really long.  The restaurant itself is nice with a community table, counters and tables for 2 or 4. Overall, sad to say but the prices are in line with what you'd expect to pay right now in SF even for a quick, casual meal - with tax and tip, the lamb, yogurt and ice tea was about $30.  I would recommend this place if you have an itch for some lamb gyro.
I got a chicken salad to go with dressing on the side ($15). It was great! Will definitely go again. Ordered through Caviar.

Souvla is a SF staple and while their frozen greek yogurt is to die for, I can't say the same for their entrees. I ordered the chicken salad and lamb sandwich while I was there. At $15 a dish, it's a pretty steep price point for what you're getting. The salad was colorful and tasty, including various sprouts and fruits like orange slices. However, the chicken was slightly dry. The sandwich wasn't my favorite since the lamb was exceptionally game-y which is not up my alley. So overall, the savory dishes left a lot to be desired. On the other hand, their frozen greek yogurt made with Straus milk was delicious! I tried both the baklava crumbles with honey syrup and the olive oil with sea salt and was very impressed! The frozen yogurt was perfectly tart and so incredibly smooth. The baklava crumbles kind of tasted like sweet oatmeal and had the texture of day old granola. The olive oil flavor was very unique, but a tad salty!

Souvla reminds me of the Mediterranean goodness of Zankou Chicken in LA except in a fast casual dining experience that is quintessentially the Bay.

Not knowing much about Souvla, I came to Souvla with no expectations.  As a fan of Zankou Chicken in LA, I never thought I could find something similar up here in the Bay.  However, consider myself a convert!  For all their meats, they have the option of making it into a sandwich or salad.  Considering the price, I was a little worried, but the size of the portions for both the salad ($13-15) and sandwich ($12-14) are pretty big.  

Plus, this is not your typical standard Mediterranean fare.  They combine their meats with nice mix of brightly colored veggies and cheese to make for an overall satisfying bite.  I thoroughly enjoyed my chicken, but I was not really impressed with the lamb.  However, they were good and solid bites that left me wanting to come back.

What really made me fall for this place was their frozen Greek yogurt.  As a big fan of froyo, I had high expectations for it.  The yogurt not only met my expectations but exceeded them!  It has the slight sour taste one expects from Greek yogurt and also not super sweet.  However, paired with Baklava crumble, which brings a nice crunchy sweetness, one bite from it was just amazing!

While the lines were pretty long, the line does seem to move pretty fast.  If you are wanting to sit down in the restaurant, there is limited seating.  However, with the nearby park, you could easily order to go and walk on over.

Overall, Souvla does Mediterranean food with a nice modern twist that is worth trying out if you are in the SF area!

I got the chicken sandwich and was surprisingly pleased. I chose the one without Greek yogurt since I'm lactose sensitive but it still has a light Greek ranch dressing that was so flavorful. My guests got the Greek yogurt and baklava and tea in a bottle and had great things to say about those. It was a perfect amount of food for exploring the park and the park let to sit was taken care of nicely for us to sit and eat on the beautiful day. I was happy with this Mediterranean food experience and will continue to try more from this culture!! Thanks Souvla!

Absolutely the best place for fresh, fast, and delicious food in the area.  I honestly have to stop myself from grabbing something whenever I walk by, it's that good.

Firstly, you must try the frozen Greek yogurt with olive oil and flaky sea salt.  The yogurt is thick and creamy, but doesn't leave you feeling heavy, as it's yogurt.  It's got a slight tang to it, but not as much as traditional frozen yogurt.  The olive oil and salt beautifully complement the frozen yogurt, and it's a fresh, delightful combination.  What I also appreciate is that they give you enough olive oil and sea salt so that every bite has a bit of each.  I've never tried any of their other flavors of frozen yogurt, but honestly I don't need to as this one is so good.

The rest of the menu is also delicious!  I always get either the chicken or pork salad.  They're really fresh, wonderfully flavored, and will leave you feeling very satiated because they're full of so many good mix-ins.  If you've got a bigger party, you can also order one of their full rotisserie chickens, which you see roasting at the back of the restaurant and are really juicy.

Even though there's usually a line outside, it goes quickly.  I've never waited more than ~10 minutes to order, and the food usually comes out just as fast.  I've always gotten food to go, so I'm not sure how difficult it is to find seating, as the place isn't too large.  But there's a big plaza right down the block, so you shouldn't have too much of an issue finding a place nearby.  Definitely come to Souvla if you're in the area.  The food is so delicious and fresh and everything's reasonably priced.  Make sure to get the frozen Greek yogurt with olive oil and sea salt!

Souvla, Souvla oh how I love you! It's been almost two years since I've been back to San Francisco so naturally my move was to Uber directly to Souvla for lunch. Please come up with a better choice!

It was a gorgeous afternoon and the outdoor sidewalk seating was full, but the big windows at the storefront were open and there was plenty of inside seating (I was pleasantly surprised for 1pm). They have a choice of three spit-roasted meats and one vegetarian option and you can get it in either a sandwich or salad form. I love the simplicity of this- easy ordering and any option is delicious. They also have a large selection of sides, but unless you're sharing it tends to be a lot of food!

I ordered the lamb salad, no sides, and decided to treat myself with an $11 glass of Greek rosé. (My plan was to treat myself with their froyo too, but more on that below). I was a little hesitant to go for the wine but was super happy that I did because you get a lot of bang for your buck! The guy at the counter filled my glass with a small/average/not generous pour and gave me this little tin pitcher that was filled with the rest of the wine (see picture). And wow, it was a lot of wine. Not sure in ounces, but I got 2.5 decent sized glasses out of the total wine serving! Definitely a great deal in my book!

I had been craving their frozen Greek yogurt with baklava crumbles for soo long and my plan was to get it, but I was so full from the salad (couldn't finish it and I'm a serious eater). Their frozen Greek yogurt is so good and they have four options of toppings- I can vouch for the baklava crumbles and cherry syrup but the baklava is truly what dreams are made of. 

New life goal is to always live within walking distance to a Souvla location!

Souvla is one of my favorite places to grab food in the whole city! I used to live on the same block as the Souvla in Hayes Valley, and went there their opening week. I've been obsessed with Souvla since! I used to get it about 3x a week after work for a healthy and quick meal. I moved to Duboce Triangle and my first thought was how sad I was that I could no longer go to Souvla, and only weeks after I moved, they opened this location on Divisidero. I resumed eating Souvla about once a week while I lived there :) 

Their Avgolemono soup is outstanding as is their pork and lamb salads and "sandwiches". I like how they have non-sweet options for their yogurts; my favorite is the olive oil and sea salt. When it isn't shelter-in-place time, they also have amazing breakfast options. I also love their Greek sodas, especially the sour cherry one! Sometimes I drop by just to stock up on sodas. Their Divisidero location has a really nice back patio you can eat in, complete with two levels and shrubbery. Both Hayes Valley and Divis also have some eating areas in the front as well, if you want to watch the street traffic. 

I live farther now and I occasionally order them for delivery. I've never had a problem with my order; never a missing or botched up item. 

I hope Souvla lives on forever. I don't have any bad things to say. They're just the best! I'm a Super Souvla Supporter! :)

Great place! I came solely to try the Greek yogurt. It was delicious, don't know that it's necessarily worth all the hype, but still enjoyed nonetheless. I liked the cherry syrup slightly more than the baklava crumbles + honey. It's light and tart but still fully satisfying as a dessert. 

Would totally return to try out the greater menu!

When you've live in SF for as long as I have you must have heard about Souvla. Popular for their clean and flavorful salads and wraps, it's a delight walking into the small but not cramp space at this location. The food was the obvious winner but I enjoyed the ambiance of the whole place. From my understanding they've expanded their restaurant last year with outdoor seating. They installed streaming lights throughout the patio area giving off a great visualization of how beautiful SF can be.

Food 4.5/5
Ambiance 5/5
Service 4/5

Great little spot in Hayes Valley for some Greek food and Greek yoghurt soft serve.  If you get your order to-go, it comes even quicker.  Seating can be a bit difficult depending on the time of day as it is a smaller venue.  It isn't "authentic" Greek-greek as some of my native friends would say, but I still consider the cuisine Greek enough.  Things that we tried included the following:

Lamb salad
PROS:
- fantastic quantity: actually couldn't finish it (for a salad!) and had to take some of it home.
- good amount of dressing: tip - you can always ask for dressing on the side if you're afraid it will be overdressed.
- nice portion of meat to vegetable ratio
CONS:
- none

Greek Fries
PROS:
- good quality to share
- not overly greasy
- standard fries, not shoestring and not steak fries
- crispy outside and soft inside, not soggy
CONS:
- these get cold pretty quickly unless you're sitting indoors so I would recommend eating them fast
- could use a little bit more cheese topping

Greek Yoghurt with the cherry topping
PROS:
- great quantity: almost had a hard time finishing this
- healthy! YAY! protein and a dessert all in one.
CONS:
- melts really quick in the sun so don't go sit in that Hayes Valley square unless you eat fast.

I'd totally come and eat here again.  This was on the recommendation of a friend when I was just swinging through and I definitely appreciate the note!  Parking in Hayes Valley (like all of SF) is a chore so use public transportation.  It's a quick 12min walk from Civic Center BART stop and for all the Californians out there, the weather is way too nice almost all the time as claimed to not walk haha.

If you want some quick Greek eats, this place is perfect. It's the first restaurant where I take my mom when she comes to the city. It gets crowded in the early evening so I prefer to come here for lunch or a late dinner (8ish pm). There is quite a bit of seating, but it gets a little hot in the back of the restaurant because of their rotisserie station (conversely, it's a perfect place to sit for when it's chilly outside). You have to watch out for the seats to open!

You pick either a wrap or a salad and a choice of protein (chicken, lamb, pork, or veggie). I like their salads and usually order either lamb or veggie. I've tried the pork one once, and it was also delicious! You can also get the fries on top if you're willing to indulge a little :) 

The house wine is pretty tasty (I usually get the rose), and you can even buy a bottle to go.

But the crown jewel of Souvla is, of course, the Greek yogurt! I'm still debating whether I prefer the baklava or the olive oil one, but they are both amazing. It's your regular frozen yogurt taken to a whole different level.

Came here for lunch today with a couple friends. Very friendly service, tasty lamb gyros, and quality fries. The Greek beer I also had reminds me of how Tsingtao used to taste years ago.

4-star rating for price, as lunch for 3 people quickly grew to $70. :-/ If you don't mind, then this place is fine.

We ordered the lamb salad and the chicken salad.  I didn't notice any rotisserie flavor coming through the meats.  Not the pizazz  that I was expecting or the quantity of meat either.  

Our orders were placed with the "Make it Greek" option for $1 more.  What is that about?  We came to a Greek place and we were expecting it to be Greek from the get-go, not for it to be Greek for additional money.  Still can't quite figure out what made it Greek because it didn't have the Greek taste.  The salads tasted more like Caesar style than Greek.  While it was filling it fell short on Greekiness.

The fries were good and crispy but that still doesn't make the salads worth $16 and $17.  I can get better Greek salads at other places in SF and the Bay Area for a lot less money.

We later ordered the Baklava yogurt and the sour cherry yogurt and they too were just alright.  For $5 bucks each I can get a better value elsewhere. 

We've been wanting to try Souvla and we're glad we did but I don't expect to come back to eat here again.

Souvla is an upgraded fast food Greek restaurant. They offer either a wrap or salad with your choice of meat. They have a few sides like fries and a Greek frozen yogurt. 

I normally get the pita wrap, but this time I got the salad. It was nicely dressed and came with a good portion of meat. For $15 it was a decent deal. The meats are slow cooked but could be more tender. You won't find your typical ground spit gyro meat here. 

They get busy at night and on the weekend, so be prepared to take it to go. Large groups or families are not advised.

Great place for a quick lunch.

I got the sandwich chicken and could not complain. We also added on their egg and chicken soup, which if you like saltier soups, you will enjoy a ton.

If you are having a hard time between the sandwich and the salad, I would recommend the sandwich.

I came here with a friend on a weekday night and it was actually kind of hard to get to the front of the ordering line since the entrance is so narrow!

Food: I got the chicken salad plate and found that I'll definitely get the sauce on the side the next time I come since the salad was drenched in sauce in my bowl. I enjoyed the food for the most part but the combo of the sauce and cheese made me not be able to finish my meal.

Service: Food comes maybe 10-20 minutes after you order and if you order to go it'll come faster! We sat outside and they bring the food right to you with your number. 

Ambiance: This place is extremely low key and casual! 

Overall, might not come again it was an average experience and nothing too out of the ordinary!

Whose Mary and why her chicken so expensive... haha jk.. a little 

Everyone raves about this place but for the price point, the meat is inconsistent for me. Sometimes it's drier than other days. If this was Chipotle I wouldn't trip but for a $12+ wrap or salad, I expect it to be spot on each time.  If there was an awesome dipping sauce maybe I could look past it all. I just want this to have more flavor but maybe folks like this because it's more healthy and healthy tends to be kind of boring. 

The baklava greek yogurt is my favorite thing here. Very refreshing and not too sweet.

pros:

* get their chicken wrap and olive oil + sea salt frozen yogurt + fries. this is a really good flavorful combination.

* very fast and efficient food pick up, parks nearby for you to enjoy the food

cons:

* lamb wrap is very filling but i don't think it is as good as their chicken wrap.

* place is packed so definitely order ahead of time

* sf pricing so it's a kinda expensive

Ordered lunch here from work and I absolutely loved it! The fries were really crispy and flavorful! I also ordered the sweet potato salad and it was unlike any other salad I've ever had! The combination of veggies was amazing!

Got souvla delivered through DoorDash. I've always heard great things about it and wanted to try it! While the price point is on the higher end for a salad, I have to admit that the salad is REALLY GOOD. I got a chicken salad. They definitely don't skimp on the protein! I personally enjoyed the salad more than the sandwich wrap. We also ordered the yogurt with olive oil and sea salt and that was so delicious! A great dessert to pair with the meal. :) the Greek fries were alright. It probably tastes better fresh, but since we ordered delivery, they lost their crispness. Still pretty good though!

We have been to the Valencia St. location but never the Hayes until today. We ordered take-out. We couldn't order online but the take out window ordering system was very efficient and our food was ready very quickly despite a line. Everything was wrapped very safely and tidy in keeping with SIP orders. The best part was everything we ordered was in the bag when we got home! We ordered basically everything on the menu. A chicken salad and a pork salad and the vegetarian salad. All were great.  We ordered the lamb sandwich which was ok.  The chicken soup was good. The potatoes were not good this time. They were too oily compared to usual. The French fries were not that great either. They were soggy.

Finally made it out to one of the locations after hearing so many good things. Came here on a Sunday night with 3 friends at about 8:30pm and it was still poppin'! We were able to snag a table as people were leaving. The food came out fast (~10 minutes) despite there being so many people. 

I ordered the veggie salad bowl ($13) that came with sweet potato. In retrospect, I probably should have gotten a meat on it because it felt like it was missing something, but the sweet potato chunks were huge and super tasty. However, the olives on the salad were waaay too salty and overpowered the rest of it. I also wished they added more veggies or filling into the salad such as tomatoes and cucumber. 

My friends all got wraps- one chicken, one pork, one lamb ($12 each). They all agreed that their meat was a bit dry, especially the lamb, but the sauce (yogurt based) helped to moisten it up. They said the pita was soft and the flavor of the sauce was not overwhelming. They put mandarin oranges in the chicken one, which was a great combo (maybe I'll try that one next time!).

We OF COURSE had to get the fro-yo after our meal. We got the baklava + honey, cretan wild flower honey, and by suggestion of the server- Greek Olive Oil + Sea Salt ($5 each). The baklava one was by far the best, the perfect amount of sweet paired with the sharp tangy-ness of the greek yogurt was perfect. I couldn't taste/see the honey syrup, but I didn't mind because the baklava was already sweet enough. I could honestly just eat the greek yogurt plain! The honey one was also good, but the Olive Oil and Sea Salt was the least favorite. Not sure how to explain it, but it tastes exactly how it sounds. There was just so much oil at the bottom of the cup and the overwhelming salt did not pair well with the greek yogurt for us. Love love love the greek yogurt, but would not recommend the olive oil +sea salt mix. 

I will definitely be back again!

As every other SF human, I love Souvla. 

++Weekend brunch, breakfast burrito with pork is INSANELY GOOD
++ Juicy potatoes are amazing
++Froyo is out of this world

I don't love the rest of the menu, but I am still giving Souvla 5 stars because the potatoes are that good.

Sorry Souvla but after years of coming here you were not good today. I had the lamb wrap and the pita was cold, hard and the portion was small. I know it's hard but you need to be consistent 100% of the time. After paying $17 plus tip I felt ripped off.

Souvla, oh Souvla, where art thou Souvla! I'm so glad they finally opened in the midst of corona, BUT they've significantly changed their hours. I'm usually in the city during the weekday and they're only open for dinner time. So I always miss their hours. I finally came to the city on the weekend and was able to catch them for lunch! I missed them so! The line to order was long, so I ordered online while I was in line haha. Basically trying to see which was faster and ordering online was faster. Once I ordered I waited to the right of the restaurant for pickup. Line was to the left, if you're looking at the restaurant. They have standing tables available on the street. All the chairs belong to patxi next door. But that won't deter me bc Souvla is that good! I forgot to order their fries which is equally good. I usually get the chicken salad. Enjoy!

I've been to the Divisadero location and fell in love with their fries and yogurt.  After visiting the Hayes Valley location for their fries and yogurt, the only difference here is the crowd.  This place was super packed but spaces usually open up so you kind of have to be aggressive and go get what you want.  

After dinner at a nearby restaurant, we wanted dessert but ended up getting fries too because even though we were full, good food won't stop us from eating.  Plus I love fries so I'll always save room for dessert and fries.

Service was quick, quality of food was on point

I don't know if the people who opened this spot have ever eaten Greek food or just like the style but this doesn't taste anything like real greek souvlaki. 

I ordered the chicken wrap and the chicken inside is boiled, but real souvlaki have a juicy grilled chicken, this one has like shredded chicken that is dry, not juicy. 
As soon as I got my souvlaki grease started to pour out of it. None of the tasty traditional seasonings or spices OR fillings. the chicken souvlaki has pickled onions, navel ORANGES (WTF) and some sad cheese, SPROUTS (another thing that doesn't belong) an some weak ass sauce. 

The fries are five dollars and are also dry af and have greek seasoning in the name but none of the flavor. 

Everything about this meal is dry including the pita bread. No standout flavors or good textures. Doesn't taste anything like greek food. 

I'm disappointed that I was roped in by the good reviews. This place is style over substance in a big way. If you want real greek food you can get it elsewhere. If you're looking for authenticity then Hayes Valley is not the place for you, the restaurant is representative of the wealthy techie vibe the whole area has. Style over substance through and through. :((

Tart frozen yogurt -- YUM! I ordered a regular size and asked for two flavors: wildflower honey and baklava. I thought they'd put it all in one cup, but they split it into two, which was perfect since I was sharing! Since broth are naturally sweet foods, it paired so well with the fro-yo. 

The WILDFLOWER HONEY turned into a taffy-like texture almost since it was slightly hardening sitting on the frozen yogurt.

I've had BAKLAVA a few times now, and felt there's was on the moderately sweet side* It was good, but the crispy layers were saturated with the syrup, so it ended up being like little mounds.

Ordering was simple! You walk-up and order on the right side and pick-up on the left. However, their ordering stand sits on an elevated platform, so it was hard to read the bottom of their menu which is this huge board behind them.
The green yogurt soft serve is delicious... everything else is very greasy and flavorless

it's cute but the food was okay. I got the veggie sandwich and expected more flavor and sauce that Greek food usually has but I found the entire sandwich pretty bland. I added some hot sauce but I reaaaally would've loved some tzatziki drizzled on top. the baklava greek yogurt was pretty good but a little too sour for my liking..but the baklava itself was reaaally good

I've tried to stroll past Souvla countless times only to encounter hordes of people overflowing onto the sidewalk. This makes for lots of weaving and dodging among folks who are either oblivious to the congestion that they're causing, or, worse yet, feel entitled to block the flow of pedestrian traffic. 

So I decided to see what the buzz was about with a friend while he was in town. If anything, he's even more of a well-traveled foodie than I am, as he lives in Europe and has spent significant time in Greece, among other places. So he knows a thing or two about what constitutes good, authentic Greek fare. 

We were both underwhelmed by what we got - a lamb salad for me, a wrap for him. It was all somewhat decent in a Greek Chipotle sort of way, but not knock-your-socks-off incredible. If anything, the lamb in my salad was rather rubbery and flavorless, and the whole thing was just a slog to get through when, normally, I'd be chowing down greedily if I was really enjoying it.

If there were any good points, the guy ringing orders up was friendly, and we got our orders very quickly after paying for our orders and picking up numbers to display at our table. But is it really worth the long wait? We both said no. Even if you really dig this place, you can order online so as to save yourself the time in line. 

I hate to be a hater, but I'd have to say that there are so many other worthy places to eat in bustling Hayes Valley. If you're doubting my observations, check out Ed U.'s always-authoritative review which generally corroborates mine.

There is a lot of hype for souvla. It is a decent spot. But overall (from my experience obviously), it is just decent. I have gotten Souvla twice (both the lamb salad). They give a lot of lamb chunks, I will give them that (protein quantity 5/5) which kind of justifies the price (if you can even justify a $15/16 salad). But overall, it is just bland in my opinion. The lamb is a little salty and it is not super flavorful for a salad. I wouldnt order again but I heard the juicy potatoes are really good? My friends seem to really love this spot though, so once again, all based on preference (I like a flavorful salad with lots of additions if I am going to pay for leaves LOL)

A small, cute restaurant nestled in the vibrant, foodie neighbourhood of Hayes Valley - this spot is a great greek find. The wraps and greek fries were delicious, not super expensive, and hearty. But what was the star of the show was the frozen greek yogurt with baklava crumbles and honey syrup *mouth watering!!!!* 

See photo for the frozen yogurt

One of my favorite places in San Francisco! I always get the pork salad, greek style (fries on top, don't judge me) as well as the baklava yogurt! Love getting the salad from here because it's never boring, and actually super filling. The frozen yogurt reminds me on Pinkberry which I love love love, my only complaint is that it's too small and wish it came in gallon sizes (:

Okay, I really wanna give this 3.5 stars, but I'm rounding up only bc the yogurt dessert is that good. 

But let me tell you about my real issue with Souvla. Listen, I've been here a handful of times. I know this is a personal problem, but seriously, they're catering to an eclectic SF crowd. It's Mediterranean food and they don't have a single seafood item on their menu?! Not even fish?! 

If I wanted to be a full on vegetarian, I would. But I'm not. I eat seafood. So I really, really wish they had some sort of a fish dish here. It's my only ask. I've had the veggie bowl and the veggie wrap and I'm not a huge fan. 

BUTTTT I have had their baklava Greek yogurt dessert. Omgggg. Heart. It. Seriously, it's that good. I only come here now for the desserts now. I'm still on strike over their non-seafood friendly menu. Other than that, lines get crazy. It's always packed. But somehow the line always moves pretty quick and there's always miraculously a spot to sit, even when you thought there'd be no chance. 4 stars!

A friend introduced me to this place yesterday and it was a great find for me. It is a bright and airy yet small restaurant. We got there around noon and we're promptly seated. You order at the register, take a number and sit at any table you find open. 

We ordered their salads which comes in a generous portions. The price was very reasonable. The food was tasty, my chicken salad was well prepared with lots of kale and chicken. Loved it. Did not try any drinks, but couldn't help notice the number of people ordering the frozen yogurt and looking so happy about it. Must try that next time I come back.

By the time we were leaving there was a line waiting for a table. Always a good sign.

Yummm this place is bomb! There's always a line but it goes by pretty quick. You order at the cashier and they give you a number. As for seating, it's first come first serve. It's a cute spot and I definitely dig the vibe there too. The food comes out pretty quick so it's not that long of a wait. 

You can't go wrong either salad or pita but my favorite is the lamb!! So good and the fries. There's list of wine too that pairs well with it. I'll come back here again forsure.

Favorite spot for yummy greek food. Hayes valley location is on cute neighborhood. I've gotten their lamb salad. I've even gotten their frozen yogurt dessert. Lamb salad was simple but delicious. I liked so much. Frozen greek yogurt is amazing. It's great place to spend time with friends and split salads.

Definitely recommend the salads here. I always get the lamb salad, the portions are huge and the quality is really good. I always have leftovers that are easily split into another meal the next day or later the same day. Plus the cherry greek yogurt is delicious! One is enough to share between two people in my opinion. Or the greek yogurt is just a good snack. Fries are good too.

The space is interesting with tables of four along one wall, bar seating on the other, one really long table in the middle plus a few outdoor seats. Service is super friendly!

Popular place but expensive since it's about $10 just for the wrap itself. If you want fries it's 5 just for the fries and plus 5 for desert.

I got the veggie wrap or something. Surprised it had sweet potatoes as the main filling. Strange at first but I highly enjoyed it after a few bites. 

Though the food is good but for the price you can find con. Parable for less money. But at least you'll want to try it out at least once. If you have income to spend on above pricing then go for it. It is good.

To start, I know there's a lot of rave reviews about this place - but here me out. To start, I'm a vegetarian and so obviously I didn't try most of their menu. I had the Veg Sandwich and the Greek Fries - both unfortunately very lackluster. The veg sandwich had a great sauce, although there wasn't enough of it and it ended up being quite dry. The walnuts to top off the sandwich were a great touch. But I wish I had falafel - the potato as the 'base' was dry, too heavy almost, and very plain and bland. The fries were too thick cut, and just didn't have enough on them. There was BARELY any cheese, and it would have been great with a few additions: feta cheese, kalamata olives, and some fresh cut garlic. There's a ton to improve on. Nonetheless, I know I'll be back to try their desserts, which I've heard so much about! But I'll pass on the food until the menu has more options!

I was told this is Michelle Obama's favorite restaurant. So I definitely had to come check it out ! 

It's a Greek salad place and I got the chicken salad and Greek yogurt with baklava. Since the line is generally pretty long, you want to order everything at once and then tell them you want the ice cream later. Then the host will give you a ticket to claim your ice cream when you're ready. 

The salad was big and plentiful and you can add fries on top. Talk about a dream come true?! I was unable to finish my salad and ended up taking some of it home. I was quite surprised that it had so much kale. Generally I would never order a salad with kale because it's really bitter, but this one was actually pretty good. There's also a ton of shredded chicken in the salad, yay for protein! 

If you're adventurous, go with the frozen Greek yogurt with salt and olive oil but don't bite into it because all you'll get is salt. That was my biggest mistake and ended up not liking it. I enjoyed the baklava one because it's much sweeter and easy to eat.

Disappointing Greek food. 
This place is all about the esthetics & gram worthy looking food. 
I got the pork "sandwich" aka the Pork Gyro which was $13 and was very disappointed. The meat was so dry the sauce couldn't even help it. 
I've been on the hunt for good Greek food in the Bay Area and Souvla seems to be one of the best known ones but of course I was ultimately disappointed by another expensive but subpar Bay Area restaurant.

Souvla has been one of my go-to's. It's pretty fast in terms of service, not too pricey, taste great, and it's convenient!

I recommend the chicken salad, it's freaking delicious, especially for chicken salad. Get the cheese on the side (I think they put too much).

The portions are pretty big, I'd take some home unless you're feeling hungry. Or save room so you can get their fries with garlic sauce add on! It's soooo good... 

You can one-up your meal at the end with a Greek yogurt dessert. Not many people know this but you can choose not just one, but TWO toppings, just tell them you want half-half. I usually do baklava and cherry. But a half-sea salt topping sounds pretty enticing now that I think about it.

Overall, I'd say that you should plan on sharing the fries and dessert with 2-3 people with an entree each.

The one major gripe I have is that they do not massage their salad, it's pretty damn raw, and there's been a few times where it's to raw for a nice salad.

If they change that up, it's an easy 5/5.

ProTip: If there's a long line, just order through their website, this has been much faster than waiting in line for me. You can specify that you want the food in regular dine-in plates and they text you when you're order is ready so you can snag a table earlier than if you waited in line to order. It's super convenient.

Souvla is quite good but they're really doing their own thing. 

For the most part, the flavors are great, although I'm not a fan of the orange slices in their chicken wrap. Quality is generally pretty high, although their trimming of the chicken left something to be desired.

I haven't had anything here that I would consider bad, but there are these occasional moments where the flavor combinations leave me scratching my head.

Went to Souvla with two friends before going to a show. Overall the food was good and our rating mixed between three and four. I had the pork in a pita. Overall the flavor was good but the pork was a little dry. The juicy potatoes were fine but nothing special. My friends had the fries and this were really good and well seasoned. The garlic aioli was good but did have a strong Greek yogurt flavor.

Greek meets hipster?
Or something like that. 

A pricey meal for a quick lunch, but it was pretty good. I got the chicken gyro and my partner and I shared the fries. Fries were tasty and crispy. Everything is incredibly fresh, beautifully presented and unique. We thought the pork was okay, but the chicken gyro was yummy. It had slices of orange or some sort of orange citrus fruit in it. We had to add some of the hot sauce for some extra flavor. The portion sizes are deceivingly huge. 

I can totally understand why people like this place, but for me it didn't impress. Definitely worth a try and it may be your jam even though it wasn't mine.

Souvla is the best restaurant in SF, hands down. It is consistently busy, and for good reason. 

Things that I love: You order at the counter and they bring your food out to the table. It comes super quick, too! The menu online shows calories - everything is healthy AND delicious. The menu might be limited, but they serve wine, beer, french fries, frozen yogurt... what more could you want? There is nice outdoor seating. The list goes on! 

As far as the food goes, order the salads! I could seriously eat the pork salad for every meal. It's really delicious and a perfect size. The lamb salad is excellent as well. Don't forget to order a frozen Greek yogurt with baklava to go!

Omg. I never had Greek food before but this place was so good. The Baklava Yogurt is the besttttttt yogurt I ever had in SF so far. The pork sandwich and lamb salad was really good and filling. I loved it! I would come back here! For the price and the portions. I think it's fair and worth it!

So one of my best friends claims she could bathe in Souvla salads she loves them so much. I had to see what all the hype was about and see if I too could find that much happiness in a salad. We ordered delivery on a weeknight. I went with the veggie salad- added white sweet potatoes-Greek style. Greek style is when they add French fries on top of your salad  because fries are the new healthy... salad was good but the potatoes and fries made it a little too potatoey and soggy.
