Mainly my fault for ordering but I was not as impressed as I thought I would be. Also tried out the honey baklava Greek yogurt. Strong flavor but still very good. Overall, I would suggest going to the restaurant to eat your food instead of delivery because it just isn't the same. Hopefully your Souvla experience will be more batheing-worthy than mine bath

Take two: ordered Souvla again and this time I was well prepared for what to order. I went ahead and ordered the veggie salad again which comes with white sweet potatoes. Skipped the onions and olives, with dressing on the side. No Greek style either (fries on top). I added my own blueberries and avocado  + chia seeds. Top notch creation right there. Souvla is growing on me, but it's not quite bathe-worthy yet!

Souvla's back, baby! I've now ordered delivery twice (once as soon as they reopened and then again after they temporarily stopped online and delivery orders) and am just as enamored with Souvla as ever. I love their lamb, so my first delivery order was the great-bang-for-your-buck lamb salad, and the second was a lamb wrap. They were both just as good as I remembered! My partner also loves wraps and requested fries both times. Unfortunately, fries just don't travel that well (no matter where they're from) so just something to keep in mind when ordering!

SF staple so not much to say: limited, but consistent and sufficient menu items. You can get the wrap or salad with different proteins. I enjoy their salads a lot. Usually with the lamb. The dressing is perfectly light but very flavorful and the greens are fresh. Their fries were decent as well. But the superstar is always the frozen greek yogurt (I like it best with the baklava crumbles) that actually tastes like yogurt and not just another soft serve ice cream.

Came here at 6:30 on a Thursday night and there were only a few people in line. I ordered the lamb salad and the portion was huge! I think it may be more worth it than the sandwich? The lamb was just ok to me but it was a hefty salad with a lot of different veggies (kale, lettuce, radish, onions). When I left the line was twice as long and out the door.

Seating is really limited, some indoor and some outdoor. May be good to sit near the park when the weather is nice. Not sure if I'll be back for the sandwiches/salads but I would like to try the frozen Greek yogurt! It looks so good!

Baklava Greek yogurt dessert- that's where it's at! 

Swung in on a random late Sunday afternoon and this place was packed! 

We lucked out and snagged the last two open bar seats and shared the dessert. It was smooth and creamy with the Apple pie flavored topping that was perfect with every bite. 

Can't comment on the rest of their menu but glad I got a chance to try the dessert. I'll have to come back for dinner for a more thorough review.

So delicious. Stopped in here for great inexpensive food and was not disappointed. I had the sweet potato vegetarian sandwich and it was better than expected. I'm not usually one for olives but it was the perfect addition in this sandwich. The hot sauce had a nice flavor too! Super fast and excellent service. 

My brother got the frozen yogurt with baklava which was a nice combo of sour and sweet. Not quite my thing but it was not bad at all. Next time I would try the sour cherry sauce. 

Thanks for a delicious meal!
Go to lunch and dinner spot with the hubby. Love both the sweet potato salad and vegan meat alternative salad. Amazing every time
Any time I'm my family & are in the city, we try to visit this place.  Great gyro sandwiches & very good service!  Love the cleanliness too.  Highly recommend!

Such a good place! Most of their menu is gluten free as is (sandwiches and pita are obviously not). I was told that their fries are the only thing fried in the oil so they're celiac safe. Tuvunu mountain tea is a must try!

A co-worker invited me out to eat, his pick and I ended up here. I'm not to fond of the area but the wait wasn't long at all. I need to mention this is pre- COVID so we were pretty packed in. I didn't mind since it was a cold evening so body heat was keeping me warm. Food is BOMB AF! I ordered the chicken sandwich with a side of Greek fries and left without a doggy bag. This is the type of place you would drive out of your way for.

So three stars for my vegetarian lunch. I think this place is probably much more enjoyable if you eat meat. Their chicken and lamb looked delish. The veg sandwich needs some rethinking -- it was thick slices of sweet potato on a thick pita bread, needs something crunchy to break it up. I couldn't even finish it unfortunately. The fries were really good though and my BF enjoyed his lamb salad. 

I wouldn't come back but worth a try if you're carnivorous.

Yum. yum. YuM!!!!!!
I wish I had been more hungry to try all of the things that I wanted.  We kept it simple with a Greek salad and french fries.  100% delish.  
We sat outside and it was lovely.  
I must go back to get the frozen Greek yogurt with baklava on top.  #drool

Ordered the chicken salad and guess what was inside as well. A fu*king plastic wrap. Absolutely disgusting. Even feeling more iffy about where this plastic sh*t would've come from especially during COVID season. Salad is pretty mediocre too. Don't ever come here. The hype is all nothing but a bust.

It didn't blow me away but it was solid. Their meats are definitely what they do well - which is good because that's how they market themselves. 

Both the chicken and the lamb wraps were quite good - lots of meat and interesting things paired with them. As usual, could have used more sauce. Nice pita. 

I was underwhelmed by the fries. There was nothing wrong them. They were crispy and hot but the menu made it sound like they would have special Greek flavor and they just tasted like fries. 

Side salad was standard Greek salad - I enjoyed that they added kale. 

They clearly are also know for their frozen Greek yogurt. I'm not a frozen yogurt fan, but my friend got one and I tried it and it was definitely unique- I can see how it would be popular. 

Very busy at lunch, but it's counter service and they move it along pretty quickly so not a problem.

Like 3 months late on the write up about Souvla, but it's definitely worth one.

Like most reviewers mention, space is in pretty tight confines so you might have to expect a little snug action. Especially considering that this place typically has lines of hungry eaters looking to get their fix of those succulent Greek creations. We made it in around lunch time the day of our visit, luckily the line wasn't too long and their was a considerable amount of open seats available, though it still felt kind of cramped. Consider that your warning.

As for matters germane to the food, I can tell you they make one heck of a good chicken wrap. It felt like such guilt free eating but without the lack of flavor. The chicken was so flavorful and the accompanying fixings only made it better. Washed down with a Greek sparkling water - I tell ya, not a bad way to lunch.

I did skip the Greek yogurt but for one, I wasn't aware it was one of the popular items, and two, I was completely satisfied with my meal. 
If you ever find yourself in the Hayes Valley area, you def owe yourself a visit for what can be a delightfully light meal.

Came here with my boyfriend on a Sunday evening around 7pm and there was barely any wait. The place was pretty busy but we quickly ordered at the register and found ourselves two seats by the side counter. There's a small but nice outside seating area for good weather. The waiter brought out our food pretty quickly. I ordered the chicken salad which I absolutely loved. My salad had fresh orange slices and light dressing that tasted refreshing. My boyfriend ordered the lamb salad which was also tasty with very tender lamb however it was pretty greasy at the bottom.  We also ordered the garlic fries (how can you eat Mediterranean food without fries??!) and they were super crispy and fresh. The portions were pretty large so I had enough for a meal the next day!

As for dessert, my boyfriend ordered the baklava frozen yogurt because of all the positive reviews we've read. Tbh, I thought it was too sweet but then again, most baklava's are! The sweetness is balanced out when paired with the tartness of the Greek yogurt so it wasn't too bad! I definitely only had one bite though and he devoured the rest!

The BEST salad you'll find in SF! Somehow they make kale salad extremely delicious, and the fries are the perfect pairing with the salad. Might not be the most healthy salad ever (with the amount of dressing they put on) but it's definitely one of my favorite salads ever

It gets pretty busy during dinner time but people come in and out of the store pretty quickly! There's also an extremely cute little outdoor eating area.

Great food but seating is way too limited. 

Tip: get here early!!!!

FOOD

Lamb gyro: 4.5/5

This is delicious. I loved everything about it - the cheese, the meat, the oil - BUT they're missing French fries! I'm a firm believer that every gyro needs fries and this one sadly didn't come with it  it's also really messy to eat and I now have more than four too many grease stains on my pants

AMBIENCE

It's a very casual place to dine and with very limited seating. Good if you are only meeting a friend or two, because there are not many tables and the inside is cramped. We were able to get seats outside but you sit along a long table shared with other patrons, and the seats are extremely difficult to move. 

SERVICE

Once you've waited in line and ordered, the wait to get your food is super short, less than 5 minutes. I really like that there's a little pickup window, especially since it's a small restaurant.

So glad we finally got to eat here! They do their own chicken rotisserie and the meat is very tender and tasty. Selection of meats are pork, lamb,
Chicken and there is a vegetarian option of white sweet potato. You can order either sandwiches or salads. We had the chicken and lamb sandwiches which were both delicious! Good sized portions and conducive to sharing. There are some sides too. I heard the fries are good. Wide selection of drinks. They have soft serve Greek yogurt which I need to try next time when I save room for dessert. Sandwich prices average $13. Good friendly service and clean interior.

I love Souvla! You can count on delicious food every single time and with every item on the menu. The menu itself is pretty small, but all tasty. There are three meat choices, which you can make into a sandwich or salad. Plus, a vegetarian option. There are also delicious sides like fries and soup. Plus, I live for the baklava soft serve!

Souvla isn't cheap. It's very easy to spend $20 with just a sandwich and drink. If you want an appetizer and dessert, it can easily double.

The Mission District and NOPA Restaurants are much more spacious and comfortable. Unfortunately, the Hayes Valley Restaurant is smaller and more crowded--no room to breath and very loud during busy times. Out of the three, Hayes Valley is cozier and closer to more boutiques.

Because of the proximity, Hayes is my go-to, but the NOPA space is my favorite!

Pretty poppin' space! Had the lamb wrap which was delicious. Their table hot sauce was definitely a high light. Great place to get a quick bite or take out. Not exactly good first date spot and parking is horrid -- but that ain't their fault.

Pork salad and chicken salad. French fries are some of the best in town. 

The Greek yogurt is good, but I don't actually like baklava that much. I usually go plan or get cherry. Kinda wish there was a chocolate topping :) 

The wine is really good too.

I'm a huge fan of this meditarranean restaurant! It's located in my favorite district; Hayes Valley. People are sitting outside of the shop, inside, and even by the windows!

This place smells of fresh roasted lamb, Greek scents, dessert, etc. I ordered their popular pork and lamb wraps which were super big. I couldn't believe how big these gyros actually were. For the price, you'll get a wrap that can feed a person and half. You have to pair your entree with Greek fries which are golden crisp fries topped with feta crumbles and parsley. I recommend ordering two sauces; Granch (greek yogurt and ranch) and the creamy garlic! It's legit bomb!! Two wraps and two greek fries ran me about $40 which seems pricey but honestly worth every penny. 

Their meat is tender, juicy, and fresh off the grill. They don't skimp on any ingredients or flavor for that matter. Souvla has officially become one of my favorites in the city! I will start coming here for lunches whenever I'm around the area. There's no going around it.

Zorba would be proud!

OK, I know! Anthony Quinn was not Greek! He was actually born in Chihuahua, Mexico, but that is besides the point! The food that they serve you at Soulva may not be "authentic" Greek food you would find in some family owned Greek restaurant on some Greek Island, but it sure tastes good! I was there for a quick lunch and had their Superior Farms Lamb Leg Salad and boy did I enjoy it! I would've loved to try one of their Frozen Greek Yogurts too, but I ran out of time. If you are in Hayes Valley and hungry, you should consider Soulva. The food is good.

Souvla serves fast-casual Greek/Mediterranean food perfect for lunch or dinner.. or both!

Let me start with the fries.  Oh man, the fries were really good.  I got it with the Garlic Dressing on the side (+$1), as recommended by the cashier.  It was well cut and seasoned, which was great, but it would be even better if I had more of that dressing!

Their Greek Yogurt was ah-mazing.  It's such a nice treat that is simple yet the flavors are so complex and the yogurt itself has a nice consistency.  My favorite one so far has to be the Baklava with Honey Syrup.  It comes with chunks of baklava and honey drizzle!  The Greek Olive Oil one was pretty salty and I don't see myself ordering that flavor again.  These yogurts are $5 and come in a cup, which is actually a decent amount of yogurt.

The Mary's Free-Range Chicken Salad ($14) Greek Style (+$1) was also delicious.  It came with a medley of different ingredients, including Mandarin oranges!  I enjoyed this salad and the portion was huge!  Greek style means adding fries on top, and I recommend doing this because the fries are so good and fries make everything even better!

I ordered the Pork Shoulder Sandwich Wrap and was highly disappointed.  The meat was super dry and you could taste the dough flour of the wrap.  And how does one eat this without everything falling apart?  I think I'll be sticking to the salad versions and other meat options.

One thing I love is that you can see the meats roasting in the back.  Service is usually friendly, though my sister and I did have one instance where a woman was rude to us because we had not decided on what to order yet.  Besides that, they're pretty quick and welcoming for the most part.  This place can get pretty busy, but they get your food to you as quickly as possible.  They have a few locations around the city, so I recommend trying Souvla out at any of their locations if you're nearby.

It's souvla.

Need I say more??

This place is a San Francisco (and definitely a Hayes Valley) staple - and for good reason too.

You want a salad? They got it.

You want an authentic tasting Mediterranean wrap? They got it.

You want the most amazing fries you've ever had? They got it.

You want a yogurt dessert with the perfect topping options like baghlava? They got it.

You want a glass of wine with all that? They got that too!

You honestly can't go wrong here. The line is my least favorite part but even that doesn't go on too long usually.

I am addicted in this place. If I were to check in every single time I eat here, it would honestly be embarrassing (haha). 

My favorite is the chicken salad; they use creamy greek yogurt for the dressing, together with olive oil, and it's simply delicious (and not heavy at all!). 

The meat is juicy after cooking and marinating for so long. I love the touch of tangerines on top!

Pro tip: you can add their special Greek fries on top of the salad as an extra. Also, always go with the "granch" dressing!

P. S. Their red wine is amazing too!

Classic spot in sf for quick but delicious Greek food. The chicken salad is a personal favorite for me and is quite large and filling. Overall would rate it between 4-5 stars but the baklava frozen yogurt truly brings it to a 5 for me! The sweet baklava paired with Greek yogurt is to die for.

Highly recommend the chicken sandwich greek style (with fries). This was such a delicious and light sandwich. The baklava frozen greek yogurt was also amazing! A great contrast between the sweet baklava pieces and the plain slightly tart greek yogurt. Great friendly service, indoor and outdoor seating options. Can't wait to be back!

My holy grail of yummy food. ALWAYS hits the spot. The tenderness and flavor of the chicken, the juiciness of the potatoes.. my mouth is watering now. I always order the vegetable salad with rotisserie chicken. 

Only "negative" through COVID is that they have been shutting off all orders (even if you drive there and try to order in-person), which often leaves me disappointed hours before they close ):

This place has been on my "to try" list for the longest time. Sadly, I think it's overrated.

EXPERIENCE: Inside, the restaurant was a bit warm and stuffy. It ~was~ a warmer day in San Francisco, so I bet it usually isn't that unpleasant. Service was quite strange. We opted to sit outside and the staff member walked up to our table to tell us that our food was ready. I was so confused why they didn't just deliver the food to our table if they were gonna walk over to us in the first place. I've never been to another restaurant that's done this so I thought it was really weird. Gave me bad vibes.

FOOD: At least the food came out super quick after placing our order...
- My boyfriend ordered the chicken pita wrap, which was small, dry, and plain. There wasn't enough sauce or flavoring so each bite tasted mostly like plain pita bread or plain chicken. Though the protein was cooked well and the wrap tasted fairly fresh. 2/5
- Lamb salad was pretty tasty. A lot better than the chicken wrap. The lamb was juicy and had a lot more flavor. 5/5
- French fries were amazing though. Perfectly cooked and seasoned, they were thick fries that were crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. I was surprised how long they stayed warm. 5/5

Experience gave me weird vibes. At least the food was yummy. Just don't get a wrap.

Souvla knows how to do fast-casual dining right! You will be a-d-d-i-c-t-e-d to their rotisserie roast chicken. Mix that in with some greens, radish, onions, oranges, and a sprinkle of cheese, and top everything some a lite yogurt dressing...boom! A delicious salad that doesn't leave you unfulfilled and sad.

The plain frozen yogurt, in my humble opinion, is to die for. Seriously. Just enough tartness and just enough sweetness for you to crave it again and again. I'm not a toppings person, but I'm sure the other options taste just as amazing. I'm writing this as I'm licking my yogurt spoon clean. YUM.

Some of the highest quality fast casual I've had in San Francisco.  They have a pretty simple menu with lamb, chicken or pork in a sandwich or salad form; they really focus on doing those things well.  Limited seating so hopefully luck is on your side, but at least there is a nearby park to eat at if you must take your food to go.  

Lamb Sandwich: In San Francisco, my biggest complaint about a lamb shawarma or gyro sandwich is that the meat isn't properly crisped then thinly sliced when it should be.  The lamb here unabashedly comes in tender chunks without any pretense of trying to be a shawarma/gyro and I'm perfectly fine with that.  It's super tender and bursting with flavor.  Plus the generously creamy harissa yogurt sauce just takes it to the next level.

Chicken Salad: I'm really not a salad fan, but this salad could change me.  For one, they let meat, creamy sauce and cheese dominate the salad with veggies just making a guest appearance.  And then the chicken itself is heavenly.  Salty, cheesy, juicy, tender.  And the portion is ginormous.

Greek Fries: Thick cut and crispy all around.  Not as mind-blowing as the mains, but still solid.

The food is generally good and fresh but a crucial thing that has made me stop ordering from here is the fact that their delivery bags do not have any kind of closure, they're just completely open flimsy paper bags and not even stapled shut. There have been times where I've had noticeably little meat in my wraps but there would be no way to know if that was just the restaurant's fault or a shady delivery driver. It felt very unsanitary.

This location has had a line every time I've come, but it moves quickly! Seating gets dicey but it's a pretty fast casual place, so a spot should open up quickly.

Menu is salads, wraps, fries, greek yogurt desserts, as well as a nice offering of beers and wines! My go-to is the chicken salad here which runs you about $13 - a bit pricey for a salad but super filling and pretty delicious! The mandarin oranges taste great with the "Granch" dressing and the chicken has always been cooked well. 

One thing to note - this is also one very few "casual" places with lamb that actually does NOT taste game-y to me. Go Souvla!

Only one bathroom, which I always found odd considering how packed this place gets but that's what you get for occupying a small place in Hayes Valley.

Anyways, tldr: solid place for a quick, healthy bite!

I walked into this place and instantly fell in love. It has a boujee-hipster post yoga work out vibe,  but they pull the look off well. The line was out the door, luckily this place is efficient. Ordered pretty quick and was able to snag a couple of seats in this packed place. I was shocked how quick the food came out, they are extremely efficient. All the staff members were hard working, diligent and committed to giving good service. 

I ordered the Pork Shoulder sandwich with a side of the Greek fries, with the garlic yogurt dipping sauce. For the dessert, baklava frozen yogurt. 

The Greek Fries- absolutely a must. They are cooked so delicious and are seasoned to perfection, such a good flavor to them with all the spices. Good alone or good with a dipping sauce! 

The Pork Shoulder Sandwich- absolutely fantastic. The pork was fantastically cooked and so flavorful, paired with all the toppings is just a flavor explosion

Baklava Froyo- the baklava topping was just what you want in a good baklava, it's acidity complemented the froyo very well.

Amazing quality ingredients! Couldn't pass up their Greek yogurt and baklava crumbles on top seriously amazing for a hot day. I've also had their gyros and they are great quality but smaller than other Greek places for the price. The sell their gyros In a salad version which looks amazing!

SOUvLa, you are the SOUL and very definition of San Francisco Greek-American casual comfort fare, and you never fail to disappoint. You are consistent and reliable - the constant in the sometimes hectic SF city life.  One of the remarkable places that sway me to say YES to haYES valley meet ups with friends on the weekend - when I'd rather be a couch potato and see what's new on uber eats. 

Things I like about Souvla -

(1) Keeping things simple, and in doing so delivering high quality at no sacrifice to efficiency.  I like that the menu is simple.  

Four proteins. Chicken. Lamb. Pork. Veg. 

Two styles. Wrap or salad. 

And honestly, you can't go wrong with any combination. My favorites? Chicken salad and Veg wrap. 

(A) The Chicken Salad: Rarely do I eat salads, but love that this salad does not seem to be a salad, rather a more complex meal. It is not overly drenched in sauce, but a flavor burst of thoughtful ingredients - the herby fennel, with the citrus bust from naval orange, and the tartness of the pickled red onion, which complements the creamy feta cheese - all carefully tossed in "granch" dressing. 

(B) The Vegetable Wrap: I love the warm pita bread hugging the roasted white sweet potato like a comforting blanket around a most delicate angel skinned white potato baby, drizzled with garlic yogurt, sprinkled with the savory kalamanta olive, with the nutty aroma and crunch from the roasted walnut, on top which the pickled red onion, crisp pea shoots and mizithra cheese sit so delicately. 

(C) Juicy Potatoes and Greek Fries: I love the potato sides at Souvla, whether roasted or fried. It always compliments the main dish so well - and is fun to share. The juicy potatoes are so moist and tender - picking up the beautiful juices of the rotisserie drippings and oregano. The Greek fries are cooked to a perfect crisp, with every bite flavored with olive oil, lemon juice, parsley and mizithra cheese. Yum. 

(2) But my absolute favorite part? The creamy, rich Greek yogurt soft serve. 

I absolutely love the glorious Baklava Crumbles and honey syrup Greek yogurt. It is essentially a deconstructed warm, just out-of-the over baklava sitting on top creamy Greek soft serve yogurt that is rich and buttery to a fault. All drizzled in honey syrup to add that sticky honeyed element. It is hands down my favorite Greek frozen yogurt in the city. 

Souvla, I am souvlucky to have you in my life!

Saturday afternoon close to 2pm and line is still out the door. My sister and I ordered the weekend brunch special lamb wrap with scrambled eggs (offer ends at 2pm) so we barely made it. The chicken salad and the Greek fries with the harissa mint dipping sauce ( you have choices of dipping sauces for your fries) portions are huge so one can basically share an order of each but can understand if one doesn't because it is that good! Let's start with the chicken salad - super fresh, perfectly seasoned rotisserie chicken and plenty of it in the salad. You get chicken with every single bite! Excellent! Now the Lamb wrap with scrambled eggs. Can we talk about the bread - fresh baked fluffy chewy pita bread! And the lamb again perfectly marinated and delicious! Very hearty meal - we put a lot of the hot sauce (not spicy) to compliment the wrap! It was EGG-cellent! Finally the fries! Hot with the right proportion of golden crisp! Love the dipping sauce! Service was super speedy quick! Crowded but was able to find seating right away! Great place with excellent delicious food!!

Quick Review:
Solid sandwiches. Tender lamb and the chicken my friend got smelled superb. Those Greek fries are also perfectly seasoned and a tasty side to your sandwich. Good atmosphere to hang out and have a heated debate with a friend about gender roles. Really enjoyed it.

One of my favorite go-to restaurants for lunch when I'm in the city! You'll order at the bar and then find a seat, which is first come first serve and can be pretty busy. 

I love that you can get their dishes in either a salad or sandwich. I recommend the lamb or pork, I usually get the salad with a side of avgolemono soup, so yummy! No meal would be complete here without a side of their creek fries. I also highly recommend their frozen yogurt with baklava crumbles & honey syrup, order after you've eaten so it doesn't melt.  

Overall, the food has a lot of flavor and is comparable to SF's often high prices. If you're coming here with kids, seating can be challenging. I recommend getting food to go and eating at a park. I would recommend giving Souvla's a try if you haven't already.

This spot serves the usual yum things and they are really good to grab and go! Eating at the Patricia Park tables has never been so easy. Lamb salad is always my favorite together with the juicy potatoes, you can really never go wrong! Their ordering system is a bit confusing because you can't do it there, needs to be online but still really worth it !

5 stars for the greek yogurt topped with olive oil and sea salt! The froyo was creamy, but not very sweet or tangy.which went really well with the savory elements of olive oil / flaked sea salt combo. I am still dreaming of this dessert from Chicago! 

Lamb gyro was good too, but the meat was under seasoned. The hot sauced help, but the lamb should be seasoned with additional salt and herbs. I see most people ordered salad here... perhaps that's the thing to get next time.

If I'm honest with myself, I probably was drawn to Souvla due to the Anthora coffee cup designs that I saw through the window.  Seeing those cups always remind me of New York City, and I can always use a place that serves good Mediterranean food!  

I thought Souvla had some nice aspects to it.  The restaurant has a sleek ambience that works perfectly for a casual dining establishment.  In terms of ordering, you can decide between various protein or vegetarian choices in either a sandwich or salad form; I was torn between the chicken and lamb, but I finally decided on trying a chicken sandwich.

To their credit, the chicken was juicy, and I liked the contrast between the savory meat, pickeld red onion, and navel orange chunks.  However, the bread was tough, contradicting its seemingly fluffy appearance.  I also tried the greek fries, tempted by the combination of olive oil, lemon juice, and cheese, but I found it surprisingly bland given the stated ingredients.  While my meal may have lacked some spark, I thought the frozen greek yogurt was a wonderful way to end my dinner.  I tried the baklava topping, and while I don't think the texture captured that flaky, filo dough goodness, I enjoyed the combination of honey, nuts, and that chewy/sticky texture that you get with baklava.

I'd probably go back again (at least for the greek yogurt), but this place turned out to be overpriced for what you end up getting.

Souvla is a must try if you're in San Francisco!! The food is flavorful, homemade and just amazing. Absolutely love the generous serving sizes and the vegetarian option( pictured below). I'm not usually dessert person but Souvla gets me every time. I've never had anything like the frozen yogurt here. It's creamy, rich, not too sweet and pure heaven with the baklava sprinkles. 

Parking can be difficult in this area so plan on walking.

Wowza! Not the first time I've had olive oil and sea salt on fro yo, but by far THE BEST. The fro yo had an amazing texture and taste and def the best olive oil I feel like I've had in recent years (and I've had Good oil) this was perfection. Can't wait to return and try the sour cherry and fries!

Just ok. The salad is the best option as the sandwich was dry and they charge for extra sauce. But what really gets me is that the environment is not inviting and service needs to learn a thing or two about how they treat paying customers. For to-go orders, they should clearly state that seats are for dine-in customers only and to-go patrons should wait outside. As I sat (the restaurant wasn't overly crowded and had other open seats) the cashier stopped the line and came over and said that seats are for customers only. Customers only he kept on saying. Umm...I just ordered my meal (which was over $20 btw) and I am not a paying customer? Way to go. 

I would not wait in line for their food or come back any time soon. Sorry Souvla.

The best causal Greek and Mediterranean food in the city! There is always a line but it moves quickly. My friend and I got the **Lamb, **Pork sandwich. We also ordered the chicken salad thinking the sandwiches wouldn't be enough. But little did I know it was huge. So full of flavor in every bite. Wasn't too heavy and the meat was tender. So good. We also order the **Greek Fries. It had good flavor and it was crispy. Better than garlic fries at the ballpark. 

But my favorite dish was their **CHICKEN SALAD. So tasty, refreshing and full of flavors. The mandarins was a great touch for the salad. They are not skimpy with their meat, gave lots of chicken. One of the best salads I had all year. 

The decor is very modern comfort and the staff was friendly. Can't wait to come back and have their frozen yogurt. I was way too full to order it yesterday.

Came here and got the chicken salad. The chicken was shredded and nothing amazing. But everything else in the salad were amazing. I'm not a fan of kale but any greens used in a salad with that dressing will make it taste good. I'm not sure what the dressing was but it was delicious. All the ingredients, mainly the orange and pickled onions, worked really well together. 

I'm looking forward to coming back to try all their salads.

I read about this place from multiple SF Gate articles. Michelle Obama has visited or at least tried and is a fan of the food. It's the most popular Lyft-ed place in SF. And it's inexpensive but delicious fast food. Anyways we visited a couple of times in the last few months. This last time was after a nearby concert. They're open till 10 on weekdays so it's nice to find someplace open late-ish. The line was out the door but moved quickly. Food came out pretty quickly too. I have tried the chicken wrap during the first visit as well as the lamb wrap this most recent time. I'm not a huge fan of the chicken - it was white meat and a little dry (guess me being Asian, I like the dark meat). I had a bit of my bf's lamb during the first visit and it was good so I got it the second time and the lamb was dry and not as flavorful as I remember. Disappointed again. My bf got the pork shoulder wrap and I liked the bite I had of that. Skeptical to go again bc what if it's a disappointment again. For sides, we have tried the potatoes (concept sounds good but I found out it super oily and gross with not as much flavor as I thought) and the fries. I remember the fries being really good during the first visit but this time they were just ok. Barely any cheese, no parsley and could not taste the olive oil or lemon. 
I really want to like this place but they have not been very consistent. Next time I may just come back for the baklava Greek yogurt dessert.

this place is delicious. the chicken salad is yummy, the the fries are always good, and the baklava crumbles & syrup frozen yogurt was delicious. the yogurt was super tart (which i normally wouldn't enjoy), but somehow mixed with the baklava it worked perfectly. 10/10 would recommend. 

this place hits the freaking spot

I finally got to check out this fast casual Greek-inspired restaurant that is often hyped up by the tech people in SF. Famous for the Greek yogurt, this place hits the spot for Greek-inspired dishes, as the food is not necessarily authentic (from multiple sources). Prices are a bit high even though this place is in SF, but they do a great job presenting the dishes properly. Order at the counter and get a table marker, and then you choose anywhere open to sit. I ordered Mary's Free Range Chicken wrap, containing "Granch" (Greek ranch?), Mizithra cheese, onion, orange, and chicken. Chicken is pulled and somewhat juicy, though I can't really taste the Granch dressing. The onion and orange give the wrap a bit of a zest, but for the most part, the chicken doesn't really fit well with the other ingredients. This is definitely a more modern, fusion take of Greek food even as someone that is not Greek. The Greek fries are just fries with olive oil, lemon juice, parsley, and Mizithra cheese. It didn't taste anything special, and the citrus flavor from the lemon juice is extremely subtle. You can choose to add a dip for $1 extra, but we opted out of that. Pro tip though: you can dip the fries into the Greek yogurt for a twist. The Greek yogurt is probably the best item we ordered, as the wrap and fries failed to impress me at the very least. The yogurt is on par or as close as it gets to Ellenos Greek Yogurt in Seattle, but with a bit more creative flavors. The olive oil and flaky sea salt one I got mixes the savory with the sweet, exciting the taste buds a bit more. You can taste the freshness of the olive oil combining with the Greek yogurt, adding to the creaminess. The sea salt gives a nice contrast between the sweet and the salty, so I thoroughly enjoyed it. I would probably come back for the Greek yogurt only, but not the other dishes I ordered

Been to this place multiple times at multiple locations and enjoy it every time. I typically get frozen Greek yogurt (at $5 it's a solid value). I've tried most of their flavors and the baklava is by far the best. Would stay away from the olive oil and sea salt flavor froyo.

For sides, the fries and juicy potatoes are both great. Juicy potatoes are made with the rotisserie drippings, so not healthy but definitely delicious. 

Their solids are solid as well. Kinda pricey but large. I've had the pork one. I was hoping for a bit more meat on it but can't complain.

Overall really like this place and will continue to go back.

This is a review just for their frozen Greek yogurt! 
We got the yogurt with baklava and it was pretty delicious! The yogurt itself was only ever-so-slightly sweet, but still smooth and creamy - like a colder and better version of super market Greek yogurt. The baklava was quite sweet and provided a nice contrasting texture to the yogurt. The portion size was decent and fills up a small cup - definitely enough for one person or even to share between two! Priced at $5 which is reasonable for SF, though I wish they gave us more for the price. 

I would love to come again and try Souvla's food or any different toppings on the yogurt.

Gratifying food. 

Lamb gyro was bomb. If you're into tzatziki order it with garlic sauce on the side. It's a must. I would prefer the bread to be softer. Will order as a salad next time. Quintessential Greek fries. Picture perfect lunch. 

But let's be honest... the best, most rational reason to come here is for their Greek froyo with baklava and honey. Smooth texture, melt in your mouth yogurt with luscious honey and tender baklava. Ooooooooo yeahhhhh!!

However, some things need improving:

1. Cunning salesmanship. When I ordered the garlic fries the cashier told me the fries came with a choice of three sauces. When I checked my email receipt I saw I was charged for the dipping sauce. Meh. 

2. Service. I tipped 20% and encountered weird interactions when requesting items or asking questions.

3. The froyo center is hollow. They could be a little more generous and fill the cup properly. 

Highly recommend take out. Avoid lunch hours. Not the venue for an intimate, cozy meal. This place embodies the pure flavors of Greece but in a well groomed, glossy, hipster fashion.

This is one of my favorite places to get a salad in SF! They dress it really well and there are different meat options to choose from. The Chicken is probably my favorite out of the three, but the Pork and Lamb are also really good! They also have a Vegetarian option. 

All the meats are spit-fired and go really nice with the dressings and toppings, but sometimes there are pieces of meat that are dry and over cooked. I don't always get the Greek Fries but they are a great side to share! I recommend getting one of the sauces with the fries, I like the Garlic Sauce. 

The portion sizes here are great but if you have room after your salad or sandwich/wrap, they have great Frozen Greek Yogurt. I've had the one with Baklava Crumbles and Honey and it was really good, not too sweet with just the right amount of tartness!

This review is just for the baklava soft serve! I saw chef Melissa King post this on her Instagram and I knew I had to try it. And holy smokes, was it delicious! The frozen Greek yogurt was still a little too sweet for my liking but it was tart enough to contrast the sticky sweetness of the baklava bits. I wish the baklava crumbles had a higher nut to pastry ratio but it was still yummmmmyyyyy!

All in all, an interesting concept that is pretty well-executed. There are a couple minor things they could improve on (see above), but it's definitely well worth a try!

Souvla - the only place that will get me to eat kale. As somebody who is a little wary about eating this leafy green, Soulva definitely hits the spot. I often frequent the one on Divisadero. 

FOOD: Feeling healthier with the chicken salad, I must admit, the "Granch" dressing they provide definitely makes the whole salad tasty (but then you wonder ... is it still as healthy?). That aside, the salad has the right textures, tasty dressing, and perfect portion size. You also can't leave without getting some frozen Greek yogurt, which my favorite is half cherry and half olive oil. It's pure bliss. 

SERVICE: Speedy! 

A fast casual Greek restaurant, Souvla definitely has the right recipe down for San Franciscans.

We needed a quick bite to eat before attending a pre-ballet lecture/talk at the War Memorial Opera House and Souvla fit the bill. It's casual (order at the counter and find a seat), but the restaurant's decor is modern and the vibe friendly. The location can't be beat too. It's only a few blocks from the Ballet and Symphony, and close to bars, coffee shops, etc! 

The DH (dear husband) and I both ordered the Pork Shoulder Sandwich ($11), and Greek Fries ($4) and the Souvla Side Salad ($5) to share. The pork sandwich had minted yogurt, pickled red onions, cherry tomatoes, cucumber and feta in it. The sandwich was okay (needed a little more spice for me), but it was very hearty. I almost wished I'd ordered the salad instead which costs a dollar more. It would have been a lighter dinner. Careful with that sandwich! The juices from the meat and dressing dripped and almost got on my outfit! 

I actually enjoyed the fries and salad more than the sandwich. Even though the fries were not as good as Opa Fries, they're nicely seasoned and they're not too thick. I loved the salad! Loved how refreshing it was. I would definitely order my choice of protein on a salad next time. The sandwich was too heavy for me! 

We didn't order dessert as we had to leave and walk back to the WMOH. They do have Frozen Greek Yogurt that you can choose to top with baklava and other sweet toppings. 

Sodas, Greek wine and beer complete their menu. We just went with water as I always grab a glass of wine at the Ballet before the performance. 

Souvla is a good option before the Ballet, Opera or Symphony if you're wanting something quick and affordable!

I love Souvla and their salads. Whenever I'm craving a salad, Souvla is my go to. I got here about 45 minutes before closing time and it was surprising still packed. The menu is super simple and opted for the chicken salad and the pork shoulder salad. Note: you can also get these options in a sandwich form too (it's a little cheaper, but the salad is a lot less messier to eat)

Both salads came out super quick. The chicken salad never disappoints me! The chicken is flavorful and juicy af and goes well with the rest of the salad ingredients. Favorite part is definitely the mandarin oranges! The pork shoulder salad was really good too, although I did find a pork a little on the dry side .. don't think I would get the pork shoulder salad again though. 

Highly recommend Souvla if you're in the area and want something light to eat.

Souvla is one of my staples, I absolutely LOVE their lamb bowls "Greek style" with the fries on top but you really cant go wrong with any of their options.  The wraps are fantastic and the chicken bowl/wrap comes with delicious mandarins which I love.  All of the sides are to die for and dont forget the Froyo with baklava.

The Greek yogurt with baklava and honey is to die for. The very first time I came to Souvla was off a recommendation to try the Greek yogurt, and I have been in love ever since. 

The second time I came, I got the chicken sandwich and decided to eat it at the little park around the corner (Patricia's Green). I love love love rotisserie chicken but am often afraid that the white meat turns out too dry, and the first few bites of my sandwich were just that. Fortunately, the navel oranges were so sweet and juicy they really brought the chicken to life! Halfway through my meal I was struggling to take graceful bites - it's a very big sandwich! - and dropped two orange slices to the ground, delighting nearby pigeons. Towards the end of my sandwich, the chicken was sitting in its own juices and luckily made for flavorful last bites. 

I then turned to my friend, who had gotten the pork shoulder, and took a bite of his sandwich. Good God, the tomatoes and cucumber together made the most delicious combination with pita and pork.

When I go back again, I think I'll try the lamb or pork, but no matter what I'm saving enough stomach to get the Greek yogurt with baklava.

I've heard such great things about this place and was excited to try it after reading all the positive reviews but I was ultimately disappointed. I ordered the chicken sandwich and the chicken was dry and flavorless. My boyfriend got the lamb sandwich and he didn't like it either, the lamb had a gamey aftertaste that was too strong for our liking. Not to mention the food was overpriced! The only thing we enjoyed were the Greek fries.

I had a former coworker who got this in her regular dinner time rotation, but I never had the chance to check it out with her. On a quiet night in the office, I was thinking of her and missing her usual choice of restaurants, so I decided to check it out. 

I got the lamb salad and a Greek yogurt froyo. The lamb salad, while on the pricier side of things, was also on the heftier side of things. The lamb was moist and of the stringy variety, which isn't really my thing, but I still appreciated how it seemed to show up in every bite in large chunks. The flavor of sometimes strong ingredients (like pickled red onions and beets) were moderated by the yogurt dressing. Not the lightest salad, but it won't weigh you down too much. 3.75/5.

As an ice cream lover, many people had told me to check out the froyo here. It's light, with a brightness from the yogurt. The baklava and honey were warm and provided some texture (not really my thing, but I know that other people like it).  I would have preferred more ice cream and less baklava, but to each their own. 4/5.

A 3.6 for me.
--

Literally the next day, we get this as a group order for lunch, so here I am checking out the chicken salad with yams, in addition to the yams.

The chicken was a little bit dry, but just as with the lamb, they were generous with the portion size. Good chicken flavor. The mitzrah cheese adds a little more texture but not really any flavor to the salad. 3.5/5 on the chicken salad. The yams are straight out of a health food lover's dream-- just straight yams, well done. Those roasted potatoes are SO salty, but boy would I get them again. So velvety there isn't really any texture to them. 3.75/5 on the potatoes.

Just came for the Greek yogurt. I'd come back for that. Cute small restaurant. Nice but busy and hurried service.  Greek yogurt with olive oil and flakey sea salt is where it's at. Baklava is nice on the side. Soft and velvety not crunchy and flakey.

Out of all the Mediterranean restaurants I've been to, I think I enjoy the bowls of Souvla the most! Given your choice of protein, the diced meat is served on a bed of delicious kale lightly marinated in olive oil. The bowl is bursting with flavor, from the onions, feta cheese crumbles, and hearty cherry tomatoes. Sometimes, Mediterranean cuisine can be too oily, but Souvla's dishes are light and filling! The meat is actually cooked in front of you in an oven! I could tell that the owners went for the "contemporary kitchen" layout, featuring light wood shelving, minimalist décor, and small pots of plants. Overall, there is a clean, modern look to the restaurant, making it a trendy place to eat. 

Unfortunately, I would not recommend the iced tea. It comes in a bottle, tastes like artificial tea with preservatives, and is quite pricey. Along with that, the other drawback would be the small, cramped space that leads to competitive seating. It will definitely be tricky to fit a big group here... This is not a comfortable "sit and dine" restaurant, since there are basically only bar counter top seating and other high table seats on hard, metallic seats. Even though there are some benches in the park nearby to eat, I think the restaurant could make more efforts incentivizing people to take their time in the restaurant, socialize with friends, and have some drinks over good food. Also, there are not a lot of options on the menu, so Souvla would not be a stop for those cosmopolitan foodies searching for exquisite, complex food.

What a disappointment! They charged me for utensils but did not provide them so I had to eat my salad with my bare hands... not a pleasant COVID experience. My friend's lamb sandwich was dry and tasteless. The beer required an opener so we could not drink it. The rose wine came in a dripping plastic cup, and did not resist the walk to the park ... not a great fun picnic. Will try something else next time:(

Lamb wrap and chicken wrap were both pretty good! Their greek yogurt with baklava and honey is da bomb doe. I wish their hot sauce was hotter. It takes 3 shakes to get 1 drop so I shook that thing 200 times in one meal. Good arm workout, but I need a more effective hot sauce!

Lamb was a bit too gamey and dry.

"Hella good."

I've had Souvla bookmarked for a while and I may be the only person who frequents Hayes Valley that hasn't eaten here but better late than never I suppose.

I dined with a former colleague and had the lamb sando and we split the fries. Both were excellent and except for feeling like it was a few dollars overpriced, I really liked the food, the space, and the service. 

We came at noon and the line was out the door. They seemed to be doing brisk business via take-out as well. It was chilly today so I didn't try the frozen Greek yogurt but it looks like it would be a nice treat on a warm day.

Diversity score: IDK. Same issue w/ racial disparity between people busing the tables/cooking and "front of the house" but that's something every gentrifying eatery needs to work on. Hope manager hires people from the neighborhood, trains them, and gives them the chance to move up and take leadership positions. It's a typical hipster watering hole in Hayes so... 7/10?

I went for their frozen yogurt, and it was SO good. All the flavors of the frozen yogurt itself are plain, but they add toppings that give them the flavor. I got the Baklava Crumbles and Honey Syrup. They were very generous with the topping (a little too much in proportion to the frozen yogurt), and it tasted amazing.

Yuppified Daphne's. 
 
Don't get me wrong, I enjoy yuppified food and have no problem paying a premium price, if justified.

Souvla's marketing is on point with great buzz words on their menu (e.g. "American Homestead Pork Shoulder", "Superior Farms Lamb Leg", "Harissa-Spiked Yogurt", etc.) and hefty prices to match. If I'm going to pay 2x the price for a chicken gyro wrap, the chicken better be free-range and Mary, herself better be tending to them--am I right?

Let's start with the good. I like that Souvla's menu is very simple. Choose a protein (pork, chicken, lamb, or veggie), then decide whether you want a wrap ($10-$13) or a salad ($11-$14). Make it a combo meal with sides ($4-$6): fries, potatoes, side salad, or soup. Have a sweet tooth? End your meal with Greek froyo ($4-$5). They also have wine and beer so you can get your drank on. 

Order at the counter, get a number, and your food will be delivered to you. The space is tiny, loud, and you will have to hover for seats. Luckily, there's a quick turnover. My co-worker and I found seats in 2 minutes and received our food 2 minutes after. Great for people who are pressed for time.

Now, the not so good. We paid $40 for one wrap, one salad, and one order of fries to share (including tax + tip). Expensive for a casual, "fast food" lunch with no waiter service. At these prices, I expected the food to be Greekgasmic.

I appreciate Souvla's use of fresh, high-quality ingredients. Given how simple the menu is, it's unfortunate the food was less than mediocre. 

My Superior Farms Leg Lamb Wrap ($13): bitly.com/a/bitlinks was superiorly dry and bland. I enjoyed the warm, thick, and fluffy pita bread but it was filled with flavorless, tough, and chewy cubes of lamb (texture of well done top round). The lamb was devoid of any spices. The yogurt sauce was concentrated at the opening end of the pita so I kept reaching for the bottle of hot sauce on our table to add flavor and moisture to the rest of the wrap. I ended up using half the bottle. 

My co-worker said the chicken in the Mary's Organic Chicken Salad ($14) was dry and bland as well. This seems to be the common complaint among other yelpers with their proteins.

I couldn't help but think one could buy nearly 3 whole rotisserie chicken from Costco for $14. Yikes, I sound like a cheap phuck but at least Costco's rotisserie chicken is well-seasoned and moist. 

The saving grace were the side of Greek Fries ($4). They were piping hot, deliciously crunchy, and fluffy on the inside. The fries are supposed to be topped with olive oil, lemon juice, parsley, mizithra cheese but we barely got a smidge of each. You have to pay an extra $1 for a tiny container of dipping sauce--what the heezy?!? If you're going to nickel and dime customers, just charge $5 and include the sauce. It's an inconvenience to later find out that ketchup is not available and have to stand in line again (and that line can get long) just to buy the dipping sauce.

I doubt I would return to Souvla, nor would I recommend it to anyone looking for a legit Greek meal. It's overpriced and the flavors are dumbed down.

Maybe Uncle Jesse will go into the restaurant biz in Fuller House: usm.ag/1Mkqe4I? Wouldn't mind a bite of his gyro. Oops, did I say that?

The perfect spot for a casual dinner in Hayes Valley. When we first walked in I was struck by the clean but trendy interior design. We were there around 7 pm on a Friday and there was a line out the door, but it went fast since you order at the counter.

We got two wraps - one chicken and one lamb - plus fries. Everything was delicious - especially the fries. It's easy to make fries but not easy to do them well - Souvla does them well.

Even though it was busy we were able to grab a counter seat before our food was ready. After we ate we went back to the counter and ordered two frozen Greek yogurts with Baklava crumbles. So good! I loved the tartness of the Greek yogurt. Will definitely be back.

Charming fast-paced neighborhood joint serving up gyros and bowl of deliciousness. We opted for their breakfast gyro and so I don't think I can speak to their entire menu since the scrambled eggs weren't exactly great and needed slat, but the lamb and the frozen yogurt with sea salt and olive oil was wonderful. The Greek fries also looked superb and I am still kicking myself for not ordering them. 

Good beer and friendly, albeit chaotic, atmosphere. Even though the cashier was a little scatterbrained, the overall service and expediency was quite great. Will definitely revisit on the next SF trip.
Delicious eats! Split the lamb salad and a side of Greek fries for two people. Also, the beer is pretty good as well. And for the price, a great value!

I live close by and whenever I walked by Souvla, it was usually packed. So it definitely piqued my interest.
I came here with my friend on a Sunday for greek yogurt that my friend was raving about. I love greek yogurt in general so I thought I definitely should give it a go. We shared one and still the portion was great.
I ended up taking out the pork salad as well with garlic fries. The portion was great and taste was delish. I would definitely come back here again for another take-out if the restaurant keeps busy as it is

I like to come here for quick eats. The menu is pretty simple and has only 4 choices with either sandwich or salad bowl so it makes it easier when I get indecisive about what to order. The kitchen is also pretty fast at getting your food ready. 

I usually get the pork shoulder sandwich. The seasoning is pretty good and I like the cucumber and the tomatoes in the sandwich. The portion of the sandwich is also pretty filling, I could probably save half of it for another meal if I wanted to. 

Souvla also sells Greek yogurt dessert if you still have the stomach for it afterwards. There are also 4 flavors for the Greek yogurt. I prefer the olive oil and salt flavor because the salt balances out  the sweet and sour taste of the yogurt and the olive oil just adds an interesting taste to it. My close second is elderflower honey because it is not too sweet and kind of taste like how I would usually eat my Greek yogurt. I did not really like the baklava one because of the texture of the crumbles and the overall taste is just too sweet.

Souvla has been on my bookmarks a few weeks now after I read about it on an SF food blog (of course...)! I haven't been to many Greek restaurants so I was excited to give Souvla a try after reading so many glowing reviews. 

You order first, pay, then find a table. The menu is simple and straightforward: you choose your protein, and if you want it in sandwich/souvlaki form or salad form. 

I've tried the lamb, the pork, and the chicken in both sandwich and salad form, and the pork salad is by far my favorite!! The lamb is cut into cubes (not thin slices like traditional gyros) and is super tender and moist. The chicken sandwich/salad has the best toppings in my opinion, with the oranges and pink pickled onions. But the pork shoulder definitely takes the cake for me as the best meat!! It's seasoned and cooked perfectly. 

The Greek fries are thick and crunchy, and were seasoned with lemon juice, olive oil, and cheese! Also you can get your sandwich or salad "Greek style" for $0.50 extra, and they add fries INSIDE your sandwich or salad!!

You will be full if you finish your meal because the portions are huge. The sandwiches may look small in pictures but they definitely are not! Souvla puts a large amount of meat in both the sandwiches and the salads. I can't wait to come back and try the pork shoulder!! Mmmmm!

Greek Yogurt w/Baklava Crumbles, Syrup- #2 on the 2015 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

I only came in to try out the Greek Yogurt w/Baklava Crumbles, Syrup ($5) since we already had dinner at another restaurant nearby that didn't have an interesting dessert menu. We decided to drive to Souvla on a Tuesday night, and it was still SUPER busy around 8pm. Although there were a good amount of people waiting outside for their to-go orders, the line to place the order was luckily short, and we were able to place our order quickly. They made our greek yogurt on the spot, so we were in and out in 5 minutes. We were able to stand outside to eat it, and it was delicious!! I just wished they layered the baklava crumbles and syrup, since it's too tempting to eat them all at once, and then you're left with a lot of greek yogurt.

Overall, it's totally worth braving the crowds at Souvla to try their greek yogurt, and I will have to come back to try their food also! Parking can be very tough in this area, especially on the weekends.

Pork and chicken wraps are super tasty here! Sauce is delicious, and everything just comes together in a wonderful symphony. (The first time I had Souvla, I may or may not have shed tears of joy as I took my first few bites.) Souvla is my go-to because I know it won't disappoint. There are many locations throughout the city!  

I absolutely love their frozen Greek yogurt, and I always opt for the one with baklava topping! (The olive oil with salt one is a bit too salty for me LOL) 

The line is also usually always out the door, but it moves quickly, and food comes out pretty quickly as well.

This is my all time favorite salad place in the city! My go-to choice is the chicken salad greek style (which means a salad with a sprinkle of frIes! - what more could you ask for).

The salad is filling and flavorful and has a great mix of fatty oils from the meat which goes well with the crisp fresh veggies.

Souvla is like chipotle meets greek food but made for hipsters with no taste buds. The food here is flat out terrible. All the protein options were DRY AF. Chicken was poorly marinated and resembled boiled chicken....and this was the better of the other options we got. I got the lamb and it was mouth drying dry! No flavor whatsoever. I took 2 bites of my gyro and just tossed it. The pork was also dry and overcooked. Again no flavor. My friend took about 2 bites and tossed it too.

Only highlight was the greek yogurt ice cream but that wasnt enough.

Never again!
This place was crowded for a Saturday night. It seemed pretty trendy.  The salad tasted fresh and light which was perfect after a heavy lunch.

Always good!!! And don't forget the Greek yogurt afterwards - with any of the toppings. 

There most likely will be a line and it is hard to get a table at times so keep that in mind.

We came at night after dinner to try their greek frozen yogurt and at first bite, my friend and I were fans! You can order the frozen yogurt at the counter, where you can get the frozen yogurt to-go style and eat it in the store or take it with you. They offer a variety of flavors and toppings, but my friend and I went for the Baklava and sour cherry flavor. 

The baklava literally tasted like a chewy caramel cookie and it paired well with the creamy, tangy greek yogurt. I ordered the sour cherry and it was delicious, making the yogurt taste like a Jolly Rancher. Their yogurts are around $5, but they give a good portion in a small coffee cup. 

I didn't get a chance to try their other foods, but I would definitely want to come back to try their gyros, fries, and salads!

Souvla just sadly doesn't live up to the hype for me. Don't expect typical Greek and Mediterranean style food you've probably had at other places. Their salads and sandwiches have twists to them such as oranges, radishes, and other atypical toppings. Personally, it's just not for me but if you like new takes on classics then maybe give it a try! Additionally, I wish they had a gyro meat option but they only offer leg of lamb and the price of the sandwiches are a bit high for not coming with any fries.

I have seen Souvla all over my friend's instagram stories so many times but I never knew what it was. This place is probably the most famous (that I know of ) in Hayes Valley. 

I tried their frozen greek yogurt with baklava. I never had baklava before, but it was a very interesting experience. It sort of resembles more of a cracker than a pastry with a sweet syrup, almost honey like. I found it a little rough, but mixed in with the frozen greek yogurt, it was a perfect mix of frozen dairy with a crunch.

They have outside seating if you would like to just chill, illuminated by string lights, very pretty. Next to the place is somewhat a little park. I imagine this place would be perfect for cute little dates.

This place has a great service and the place has friendly atmosphere. But they ruin the ingredients of the salad leaves with too much cheese, olives and dressing. Their chicken, pork and lamb are great, so why do would you ruin these nice ingredients ? The best thing they have there is probably the juicy potatoes and frozen ice cream.
We do go for a take but we often end up disappointed.

The line can be long but they move really fast so wait till you can find a table. They have small selection on menu but they do it right. Great for kids too. 
Keep some room for frozen yogurt.

Souvla is the typical restaurant you'd find in Hayes Valley. Super cute, small, quaint, with a huge line out the door. 

They have great salads, sandwiches, and meats. Nothing feels TOO heavy which is amazing! If ordering for one, their portions are usually too large to order multiple dishes (IE, french fries + salad), and I rarely am able to finish the salad alone. 

I like ordering salads "Greek style" where they will put a few extra fries on top! Leg lamb salad is my favorite, but even the pork shoulder + sweet potato is also delicious!

In term so yogurts, I'm a big of the baklava greek yogurt (another very popular one is the olive oil + sea salt) which IMO blends too many flavors together. I studied abroad in Greek for a summer, and have been hard pressed to find greek yogurt comparable to ones in Athens, but this one certainly hits the mark!

Rating 4/5 because while I will always be a return customer / huge fan, seating is hard to come by and while the food is delicious, its nothing truly to "blow you away".

Fast service and delicious greek food! I especially love the frozen yogurt - so unique and healthier than ice cream. This would be a good spot for a quick lunch or dinner.

Minus one star since seating is quite limited, and the prices are on the higher end for fast-casual dining.

The frozen greek yogurt with baklava crumbles and honey syrup is delicious! That was my absolute favorite! I honestly could just eat it all day. I had the lamb wrap and it was huge! I definitely got my money's worth. One downside of the wrap was that it was very oily. In addition, I got the greek fries and they were great while hot, but make sure to eat them quickly because they get soggy fairly quickly. I hope to come back soon to try different wraps and salads and most importantly, eat for frozen greek yogurt.

I haven't been here since 2016 but I still dream about their lamb sandwich. Enough said.

*pre-COVID the place was packed during early dinner hours. Some communal tables.

Simple but tasty food! You can smell the fragrance when walking into the restaurant. The meat is roasting right in front of you.
Love the out door seating but the indoor ones are great too. Would come and try the frozen greek yogurt next time coz we are too full after the meal!

I'm usually not a big fan of Mediterranean food, but this place was really good and extremely crowded. The store is small and you seat yourself after ordering at the counter. It is kind of difficult getting a seat for 4 people, especially because each party leaves an empty seat in between other parties on the counter.
I got the pork sandwich and it's like a wrap. It had pork, cheese, cucumbers, and tomatoes. The veggies tasted fresh and really made the sandwich taste better. The sandwich also didn't seem that big, but I was stuffed after finishing it! I also got the garlic fries which had no garlic flavor what so ever, but it tasted sooo good with the greek yogurt dip that was given to us. I would definitely get the fries again, but probably just regular fries. Lastly, I tried the greek frozen yogurt and it was so good! Tasted like tarte froyo with some extra flavor from the syrup, baklava, or olive oil.

Souvla is a great, fast-casual spot for Greek food.  While it is on the pricier side for fast-casual, the quality is worth the price.  The location in Hayes Valley is tiny and can have a line out the door during peak lunch and dinner hours but the front staff is quite efficient at taking orders and getting people through the line. 

The perimeter of the dining space has either high top tables or bar seating; on the right side of restaurant, there is a long table for family style seating.  The décor has a rustic but airy and modern feel to it.

The menu has two types of main dishes: salad or sandwich.  You then select pork, chicken, lamb, or vegetable for your salad/sandwich.  I have tried both the salad and sandwich in each variety (I eat Souvla a little too often), and my favorite combination is the chicken salad.  I love making my chicken salad "Greek style" (+$1), which means adding fries on top.  The Greek fries as a side/appetizer are always a table favorite.  If you're craving sweets, definitely grab a cup of their frozen Greek yogurt.  My favorite flavor is either sour cherry or baklava.  Almost everything I've eaten at Souvla is delicious but skip their Greek iced tea.  It comes in a bottle and tastes like what I imagine bong water to be like.

I'm honestly not sure why by 7:00 there was a long line out of the door. Maybe I am losing my SF palate or I ordered the wrong thing? Apparently the yogurt, which I didn't sample, is to die for. I wouldn't die any time soon for my ingestion.

There were only four main dishes on the menu and none of them were SOUVLA-aki...I guess that's what happens when you assume things.

Anyway, I was hoping for a broader menu since I ADORE Greek food and don't have ANY decent options near where I live. I ordered the lamb and it was chewy. Not flavorless, but definitely not flavorful. 

I'd have to sum up my dining experience as, "I'm hungry and paid money for it so I'll definitely eat it." 

A great sauce may have taken it over the border from mediocre to pretty damn good. But alas, I was too hungry to find the needed fixes and once done, I was very "meh" about the entire experience. I'm not really inspired to try it again (except maybe the yogurt) since there are so many better food options in the area.

Loooove this place in Hayes Valley! Now I see why it's so busy! Although it's busy and packed the wait is not long at all. Their pita sandwiches here are amazing. Packed with so much flavor! I got the chicken and my bf got the lamb. Both were so delicious! We also got the garlic fries! Amazing! We also got the baklava froyo with honey for dessert. Everything was so delish here! Def will be back!

So Souvla has been on my bookmarks list for quite some time.  Long line as others have mentioned but they seem to do a great job of getting their items out quickly. My order was to go and I felt like I didn't have to wait too long. 

American Homestead Pork Shoulder Salad $12 
minted greek yogurt, cherry tomato, pickled red onion, cucumber, feta cheese

As others have mentioned this is absolutely delicious and vaults up to the upper tier of my SF salad rankings below and no surprise really since I've heard about this place a lot. 

I like the generous amounts of cherry tomatoes they put (I like tomatoes a lot) since some places skimp on them and Feta always makes it BETTA...

Just a great place and I look forward to trying other items. 

I like Healthy Foods...occasionally ...lol. For the past year or so I workout multiple times everyday so I typically try to eat at least one Salad a day. Often times I bring my own salad for lunch but sometimes I venture out in the city for some healthy greens.  

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. 

Here is a look at how I rank the Salad Spots in the City. They are all pretty good this is just my take. 

Rod's San Francisco Salad Rankings (and what they're known for or what I like). I have rankings various foods like Boba, Ramen, Steakhouse, Chicken and Wafffles(random right?) Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews. I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places 

Ranked from Fave to least fave (Business owners don't hate me, all these places are good) 

1 Café du Soleil-Nicoise Salad
2 SweetGreen-Pesto Chicken
3 Darwin Café-Baby Spinach 
4 La Fromagerie-La Mancha Salad
5 Mission Picnic -Deluxe Cobb
6 Souvla-American Pork Shoulder Salad
7 Mixt-Mixt Cobb
8 Plutos-Custom salad
9 La Capra-The Cobb
10 Tender Greens-Chinese Chicken
11 Soma Eats-Spinach, Date and Goat Cheese Salad
12 Blue Barn Gourmet-Cobber (Cobb Salad)
13 Split Pea Seduction-The Squash salad
14 Boxed Foods-Boxed Chicken Salad
15 Kitava-Pesto Chicken Cobb
16 Native Co-Native Salad
17 Soma Chicken-Caesar Salad
18 Proper Food-Lemon Quinoa Salad with Chicken
19 Eatsa-Various Salads/bowls 
20 The New Spot on Polk-Asian Chicken
21 Organic Coup-Kale/Caesar Combo 
22 Uno Dos Tacos-Fish Salad Bowl

Not worth the price and poor quality fast food resturant. I took two friends here and ordered 2 chicken sandwiches and one lamb plus 2 soups.   I also made the mistake of giving a 15% tip though this is not a full service restaurant. The total cost was $65.

Here is what was right with the place:

1) Workers were responsive and professional.

Here is what is wrong with this place:

1) Pita for all 3 sandwiches was too dry.
2) The lamb sandwich have very little meat.
3) Way too much cheese.
4) Though the lemon grass soup was pretty good, mine had a small hair at the bottom; not very appealing.
5) Crowd: Mostly young under 30 crowd. I have always felt that to appreciate good food you need to have spent time experiencing  different cuisines. Young people in my opinion are not the best to review food. 

A traditional Gyro fast food joint would be a better value.

Finally, WHY ARE YOU SENDING MY PERSONAL RECEIPT TO MY WORK EMAIL?  I don't want to mix professional and personal. I'm very angry about unsophisticated outfits like this  signing up for technology  they don't understand and then intruding into peoples lives in a very crass manner.

I drove all the way from Danville and waited to be the first one in line to do a take out order, only to feel completely robbed from my order. I had a big order and even ordered and Paid for the extra side of the hot sauce because the hot sauce makes the salad that much better. I even gave them extra tip. When my order finally came, I reconfirmed that they didn't forget my hot sauce. The server asked if I paid for the extra hot sauce and I said yes, and pointed at the receipt. He confidently confirmed that my hot sauce was included. I drove back home to Danville only to find out they didn't give me my hot sauce! I called and left a voice message and no one ever even replied or called me back. I know it's just a hot sauce but it's the principle. I paid for the item, and even gave extra $16 tip that they didn't even deserve for not giving me the item I paid for. I'm disappointed. I was the first one to order and it wasn't even busy. Why still get your customer's order wrong and not apologize? Sure it's just a hot sauce but really not okay!

The weeknight line out the door at Souvla caused me to walk by before circling back.  This was a place I'd wanted to try for a long time and why not let that time be now?  Smart choice, as that line is where you place your order and I learned that it moves quickly.  

Souvla's simple concept is killing it right now.  With 3 SF locations they're on the tip of becoming that thing that yelpers hate, a "chain'", but actually they're the type of chain I welcome.  I was quite happy with my salad made with free range chicken, pickled red onions, pea shoots, and more ($13), and their frozen Greek yogurt ($4-$5) with assorted intriguing toppings is a perfect inexpensive dessert.    

The concept here is straightforward, with chicken, lamb, pork, and vegetables being offered in (lavash) sandwich or salad format, all in the $10-$14 range.  The menu sources the origins of the proteins so you're not just staring down at "pork" but rather, "American Homestead Pork Shoulder".  It's the sort of virtuous menu which gives the impression you're getting fresh, responsibly sourced products.  The whole place, especially with the crowds it attracts, feels very "now".

Souvla's formula is one that several other small, local chains are offering.  Though completely different, the price point and service model call to mind The Grove and Blue Barn Gourmet, both local small chain enterprises.  Of the 3, I liked Souvla the best as result of their style, their menu, and their food.  

Did I like everything?  My dining partner ordered his salad with a protein of Superior Farms Lamb Leg which I tasted and didn't at all care for.  It took him until midway through his meal to reach the same conclusion.  Neither of us would again order the lamb.  

Souvla is a vibrant hive of activity.  I'd happily return for another salad (this time off-menu "Greek-style" which translates into "topped with fries") and frozen Greek yogurt.

I have been here many times, craving for their delicious Greek yogurt ice cream, particular the Cretan wildflower honey or baklava crumbles. Souvla sometimes does have a long line outside, but most people just get the ice cream or wraps Togo. 

The juicy potatoes sitting in the fat and oil from the rotisserie meat are also super good. Personally, I would just order one and share to enjoy the fatty carb. One disappointing thing is, even though the sight of the juicy rotating meat in the oven and the smell really draw customers in, the meat in the pita wrap is always so dry, and lack meat flavor. The sitting situation is not particular comfortable either in the restaurant. 

If there's a short line, grab some yogurt, juice potatoes, and continue shopping in Hayes Valley :)

I came across this place by chance while exploring the neighborhood. There was a huge line outside and out of curiosity I went in to have a look at the menu, I was sold on baklava with frozen yogurt. I started with the dessert and eventually ordered their chicken salad. Not being a huge fan of salad myself, that was probably the best chicken salad I have had. The interiors and architecture are crafty designed and at par with the food served. There is light, color, and open space. The service is good and staff is  knowledgeable. The order is placed at the counter and is served at the table. 
Not to mention the finger licking baklava served here. A must visit place in San Francisco.

Came here on a weekend and it was busy but not wait in like for an hour busy and while the seating was limited we got a seat pretty quickly.  We ordered the lamb sandwich, Greek fries and the baklava frozen yogurt.  We didn't have to wait for anything (ordering, seating or food) so that was definitely a plus.  We sat down only for several minutes and our food came to our table.

The lamb sandwich was okay although a bit dry.  The Greek fries were good and crunchy.  The baklava frozen yogurt was awesome and if I'm in the area again I would go alone just for that.  All the portions were good and the prices were meh, okay for SF.  Probably wouldn't visit again because the sandwich but they might have had an off day so I would definitely recommend it only if you're in the area and can't decide what to get.

Adorable place with unique food. I had the chicken sandwich with the "granch" dressing, cheese, and orange. It was a very interesting combination with the awesome rotisserie chicken. But surprisingly this odd combo worked. They also have hot sauce at the tables which is really good. My friend tried the Frozen Greek Yogurt with Baklava pieces - I snagged a bite and it was delicious. The tartness of the yogurt with the sweetness of the pieces was a perfect bite, leaving the palate guessing. Definitely a cool spot to check out!

Souvla has solid food, it's one of my favorite places to eat.  The line moves along quickly and the customer service is super friendly and helpful.  I like the outdoor patio in the back with the hanging lights, it's nice to eat out there on a sunny day.  Everything I've had has been delicious.  I like the lamb salad with fries, but the chicken is also excellent.

YUMZ

They apparently stop answering calls and turn on their voicemail at least 20 mins before closing so don't bother to try to call in an order anytime close to their closing time. I'll spend my money elsewhere from now on.

This place was hopping on a Wednesday night but I think it's hopping every night. We waited in line and placed our orders.
